{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:AdaElizabethLevett.jpg|right|thumb|275px|Staff of St Hilda's College, Oxford, including Elizabeth Levett, October 1919]] '''Ada Elizabeth Levett''' (1881–1932), known professionally as '''A. E. Levett''', was an Oxford-educated native of [[Bodiam]], Sussex, who became a pioneering woman economic historian specialising in medieval [[feudalism]]. Levett was Vice Principal of [[St Hilda's College, Oxford]], and later took up an appointment to a history chair at [[Westfield College]] at the [[University of London]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=OP5ePl7i5EIC&pg=PA348&lpg=PA348&dq=%22ada+elizabeth+levett%22&source=web&ots=aSEZZYG2iH&sig=EFeAzsm6yDE3ri9QpwDvHdD8kCI&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=10&ct=result The History of the University of Oxford, Trevor Henry Aston, J. I. Catto, T. A. Ralph Evans, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 1994]</ref>
Levett was born into an old Sussex family in [[Bodiam]], near the border between [[Kent]] and [[Sussex]], where her family had lived since medieval times. [[Bodiam Castle]] had been held by the [[Levett]] family during the sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries, and the lane near the castle was named for them.<ref>In 1623 John Levett of [[Salehurst]], Sussex, sold Bodiam Castle and the manor, which included the right to have a market, to Nicholas Tufton, 1st Earl of Thanet.[https://books.google.com/books?id=ubMHAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21&dq=john+levett+bodiam+thanet+sold&source=bl&ots=4e9JDyWUx0&sig=QjJDWdBq9i9165QGJGRcIEz96Oc&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result] The castle changed hands several more times in the following centuries. Its owners included Sir Nathaniel Powell, 1st Baronet of Ewhurst, member of Parliament Sir [[Sir Thomas Webster, MP|Thomas Webster]], baronet, of [[Battle Abbey]], and ultimately [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston]], who restored Bodiam Castle and donated it to Britain.</ref> The once-powerful [[Anglo-Normans|Anglo-Norman]] family, one of the county's oldest, had held manors and lands across Sussex. The study of medieval feudalism was probably in Levett's genes.
Levett's father was a simple yeoman farmer as well as an outdoor enthusiast. Academic pursuits were not encouraged in the household, especially for women. Nevertheless, both Elizabeth and her younger sister Mary Jane Levett (known professionally as M. J. Levett) became noted scholars.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=pRp1YdonaU4C&pg=PR10&lpg=PR10&dq=%22jane+austen%22+levett&source=web&ots=dCOoqJIjkQ&sig=Fb_t2fE0yvZzvnq-P_-k3u3hquE&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result#PPR9,M1 The Theaetetus of Plato, M.J. Levett, Myles Burnyeat, Hackett Publishing, 1990]</ref>
Elizabeth Levett graduated from Oxford, then became Tutor in Modern History, writer, lecturer and Vice Principal at [[St Hilda's College, Oxford]],<ref>[http://www.npg.org.uk/live/search/portrait.asp?LinkID=mp66755&rNo=0&role=sit Staff of St. Hilda's College, Oxford, Bassono, National Portrait Gallery, npg.org.uk]</ref> where her scrupulous research and lean writing style made her stand out, even among her women contemporaries at Oxford, who often chose the route of close archival study to set themselves apart from male contemporaries. These women were redefining the role of women at the University: women had been forbidden to be faculty members or examine for the university, nor were they allowed to take the M.A. diploma (they were permitted to take a B.A.). Oxford published women's examination results in a separate class-list up until 1952.
But some Oxford dons welcomed the new influence. Professor [[Ernest Barker]], for instance, taught both Elizabeth Levett and her gifted contemporary [[Maude Clark]] before departing Oxford to become principal of [[King's College, London]].
In her speciality of medieval economic history, Levett made use of archives in monasteries and local archives.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=CrswvYnJo5wC&pg=PA198&lpg=PA198&dq=%22ada+elizabeth+levett%22&source=web&ots=8MHubF_UK1&sig=F73CMlqGNV1CEPwDZj-fLIVx5mM&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=2&ct=result The Gender of History: Men, Women, and Historical Practice, Bonnie G. Smith, Harvard University Press, Cambridge, 1998]</ref> Her style was known for its rigorous scholarship with attention to the minutest detail. In the Ewart lecture of 1916, Levett argued for "a stricter method, more rigidly exact in its collection of evidence." Her method, evident in her deeply researched works, was typical of her Oxford contemporaries, Levett noted. No detail should be left out, she said, "not even a mouse-trap, nor even, what is less, a peg for a harp." [[Image:St Hilda's College Library.jpg|thumb|Library, St. Hilda's College, Oxford]] Her most noted works are ''Studies in Manorial History'' and ''English Manorial History in the Fourteenth Century'', but she published scores of academic articles and monographs on medieval history—from the obscure details of feudalism to more sensational topics like the [[Black Death]].
A student of the legal and social historian Sir [[Paul Vinogradoff]] at Oxford, Elizabeth Levett took up the methods of careful scrutiny of archival sources, and added an economic historian's insights. Her study on the Black Death was groundbreaking at the time, and her work on the manorial courts of [[St Albans]] was seminal in the field. (She died before publication of the St. Albans work.) Speaking of her former professor Vinogradoff, Levett said "he taught me to unify my varied interests... into the great framework of Economics and Jurisprudence, and to bring it to bear on practical social history."<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=YlgvdIX7IVwC&pg=PA7&dq=%22ada+elizabeth+levett%22&lr=&ei=Mxf7SNWWGZrStQOKtvjfCg A Woman in History: Eileen Power 1889–1940, Maxine Berg, Cambridge University Press, 1996]</ref>
This growing wellspring of women historians was especially evident in the [[Victoria County History|''Victoria History of the Counties of England'']], where much of the text was written by female medievalists like Levett, poring over contemporaneous medieval records of peasantry at the time. It was an approach that Levett herself advocated and embraced, and historians saw its impact on her own work.
In writing about the property rights of peasant women during medieval times, for instance, Levett described the sale of land completed while a distraught wife sobbed in court—described in the Latin of medieval records as ''lacrimentem in pleno halimoto''. The transfer was later voided by the court after the husband's death because of the wife's protests, but it was accepted by the court at the time. By focusing on such particular incidents in the old records, Levett limned the societal rights (or lack of them) of medieval women, who were seen as subordinate tenants.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=BlPozsV5t_EC&pg=PA112&dq=%22ada+elizabeth+levett%22&lr=&ei=nxz7SNC3MY3sswPD_ZC4DA#PPA111,M1 Women in the Medieval English Countryside, Judith M. Bennett, Oxford University Press (U.S.), 1987]</ref>
In addition to her carefully footnoted academic pieces, Levett delivered lectures and wrote articles on prostitution, on university women and religion, and on women in the postwar world. As her reputation grew, and strictures on women in academia loosened, Levett found that she was in great demand as a lecturer and writer. The award of a history chair at [[Westfield College]] crowned her career as one of a small number of emerging British women historians.
Elizabeth Levett died in 1932 at the age of 51 at the height of her professional career.
Levett's younger sister F. M. Jane Levett, early professor of logic at [[Glasgow University]], also went on to an illustrious career. She is best known for her translation (as M.J. Levett) of [[Plato]]'s [[Theaetetus (dialogue)|''Theaetetus'']]. Jane Levett died at her cottage near [[Tenterden]], Kent, not far from her Bodiam birthplace, in 1974.
==Works== * ''Europe Since Napoleon'', London: Blackie, 1914. WIth introductory note by [[Richard Lodge]]. * (with [[Adolphus Ballard]]) ''The Black Death'', Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1916. Oxford studies in social and legal history, vol. 5. With a chapter contributed by Reginald Vivian Lennard. * ''The black deaths on the estates of the see of Winchester''. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1916. Oxford studies in social and legal history, vol. 23. With a chapter contributed by Adolphus Ballard. * 'The Courts and Court Rolls of St. Albans Abbey', ''[[Transactions of the Royal Historical Society]]'', 1924. * ''English Economic History'', London: E. Benn, 1929. Benn's sixpenny library, no. 48. * ''The Consumer in History'', London: E. Benn Limited, 1929. Self and society, no. 21. * ''Studies in Manorial History'', Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1938
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Internet Archive author |sname=A. E. Levett}} * [http://socserv.mcmaster.ca/econ/ugcm/3ll3/levett/StudiesManorialHistory.pdf ''Studies in Manorial History'', Ada Elizabeth Levett, edited by H. M. Cam, M. Coate, L. S. Sutherland, socserv.mcmaster.ca]

Sipora Dvali | relatives = [[Kato Svanidze]] (sister) }} '''Alexander Semyonovich "Alyosha" Svanidze''' ({{lang-ka|ალექსანდრე სვანიძე}}; {{lang-ru|Александр Семёнович Сванидзе}}) (1886 – 20 August 1941) was a [[Georgian people|Georgian]] [[Old Bolshevik]] and historian. He was a personal friend of [[Joseph Stalin]] and a brother of Stalin’s first wife [[Ketevan Svanidze|Kato]]. Nevertheless, Stalin had him arrested during a [[Great Purge|purge]] in 1937. He was shot in prison in 1941. Born of a [[aznauri|petty noble]] family in a small village of Baji in western Georgia, then part of the [[Russian Empire]], Svanidze was educated at [[Tiflis]] and later at [[Jena]] where he learned [[German language|German]] and [[English language|English]] and engaged in historical research of ancient civilizations. He joined the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1901 and worked in the Bolshevik underground until being forced to leave [[Democratic Republic of Georgia|independent Georgia]] in 1919. He worked for the [[Russian SFSR|Russian]] foreign office in the years 1920–1921 and then served as a [[People's Commissar]] for Finances of the [[Georgian SSR]] and [[Transcaucasian SFSR]] in the years 1921–1922. In 1924, he was appointed a Soviet trade envoy to [[Germany]] and, upon his return to the [[Soviet Union]], became Deputy Chairman of the [[Gosbank|Soviet State Bank]] in 1935. At the same time, Svanidze continued his scholarship; he founded the ''[[Journal of Ancient History]]'', studied the [[Alarodian languages]], and translated into Russian the medieval Georgian poet [[Shota Rustaveli]].{{Ru icon}} [http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_s/svanidze_as.html Сванидзе, Александр Семенович]. ''Hrono.ru''. Retrieved on 2008-06-14. At the height of the Great Purge, Stalin ordered Svanidze’s arrest in 1937. He refused defiantly to confess to being a German spy in return for his life as the [[NKVD]] demanded. "Such aristocratic pride," Stalin is quoted to have said. Svanidze, his wife Maria (née Korona; 1889–1941) — a singer for the [[Tbilisi Opera and Ballet Theatre|Tbilisi Opera House]] and his sister Mariko were executed in 1941 as the Germans advanced.[[Simon Sebag Montefiore|Montefiore, Simon Sebag]] (2007), ''Young Stalin'', pp. 311-2. McArthur & Company, {{ISBN|978-1-55278-646-8}}.Rieber, Alfred J. [http://www.historycooperative.org/journals/ahr/106.5/ah0501001651.html Stalin, Man of the Borderlands] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120801112844/http://www.historycooperative.org/journals/ahr/106.5/ah0501001651.html |date=2012-08-01 }}. ''The American Historical Review''. December 2001, vol. 106, no. 5. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Joseph Stalin}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Svanidze, Alexander}} [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:1941 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century historians]] [[Category:Atheists from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Georgian Communist Party politicians]] [[Category:Georgian revolutionaries]] [[Category:Great Purge victims from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Historians from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Old Bolsheviks]] [[Category:Russian Social Democratic Labour Party members]] [[Category:Stalin family]]

{{Infobox person |name = Arif Yunus |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1955|1|12|df=y}} |birth_place = Baku, Azerbaijan |nationality = Azerbaijani |other_names = Arif Yunusov |known_for = civil society engagement |occupation = author, historian, and human rights activist |organization = Institute of Peace and Democracy }}
'''Arif Yunus''' (born 12 January 1955) is an Azerbaijani author, historian, and human rights activist. He is the head of the Department of Conflict and Migration of the Institute of Peace and Democracy. After being detained, Arif Yunus was sentenced to 7 years in jail; his wife, [[Leyla Yunus]], was sentenced to 8.5 years in jail on charges that include fraud and tax evasion.
==Life and work== Arif Yunus was born in [[Baku]], Azerbaijan, on 12 January 1955, to an Azeri father and an Armenian mother.<ref>Eynulla Fatullayev. [http://haqqin.az/news/21826 Секретное досье Лейлы и Арифа Юнусовых (фотофакты) Часть первая]. ''Haqqin.az''. 7 May 2014.</ref><ref>Thomas De Waal. [http://carnegieendowment.org/2015/01/09/free-thinker-loses-his-freedom-in-azerbaijan A Free-thinker Loses His Freedom in Azerbaijan]. ''carnegieendowment,org''. 9 January 2015.</ref> He began his studies at [[Baku State University]] and graduated from there in 1981. During his time as a student in Baku State, Arif Yunus met his future wife Leyla Yunus.<ref name=guardian>{{cite news|last1=Sindelar|first1=Daisy|title=Together a lifetime, Azerbaijan couple now separated in jail|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/28/azerbaijan-activists-leyla-arif-yunus-charges|work=Guardian|date=28 August 2014}}</ref> Arif Yunus eventually attained his doctorate in history in 1986. In 1992, working for the Presidential Office of Azerbaijan, he became the Head of Information and Analytical Department and served this position for a year. He became the executive director of the ''Azeri'' Independent Information and Analytical Center. Having served his position at ''Azeri'' until September 1994, Yunus eventually became the Chief of Department of Conflictology and Migration Studies of Institute of Peace and Democracy (IPD).<ref name=cvarif /> The IPD promotes dialogue among intellectuals in both Armenia and Azerbaijan.<ref name=hrwatch />
Arif Yunus defends those who suffer from torture and condemns the imprisonment of people for political reasons.<ref name=awid1>{{cite news|title=Azerbaijan: Front Line Defenders Condemns the Sentencing of Leyla Yunus and Araf Yunus |url=http://www.awid.org/news-and-analysis/azerbaijan-front-line-defenders-condemns-sentencing-leyla-yunus-and-araf-yunus |publisher=Association for Women's Rights in Development |date=18 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908053403/http://www.awid.org/news-and-analysis/azerbaijan-front-line-defenders-condemns-sentencing-leyla-yunus-and-araf-yunus |archivedate=8 September 2015 }}</ref>
Yunus has published over 30 books and 190 articles related to Azerbaijani history and Armenian-Azerbaijani relations.<ref name=cvarif>{{cite web|title=CV: Arif S. Yunusov Doctor of History |url=http://www.oei.fu-berlin.de/en/projekte/cscca/downloads/ay_cv.pdf |website=Osteuropa-Institut |publisher=Freien Universität Berlin }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Arif Yunus along with his wife Leyla are supporters of a peaceful resolution to the [[Nagorno-Karabakh conflict]] between Armenia and Azerbaijan.<ref name=guardian /><ref name=awid1 /> He has taken part in various conferences and seminars for such a solution to the conflict.<ref name=cvarif />
==Arrest and imprisonment== On 28 April 2014, Arif Yunus and his wife Leyla were detained at the [[Heydar Aliyev International Airport]] on their way to [[Doha]], Qatar for allegedly spying for [[Armenia]].<ref name=bbcnews>{{cite news|title=Azerbaijan's Leyla Yunus, human rights defender, held|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27202134|newspaper=BBC News|date=29 April 2014}}</ref> He and Leyla were then jailed.<ref name=RFEarrest>{{cite news|title=Leyla Yunus's Husband Arrested In Azerbaijan|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/yunus-arif-leyla-azerbaijan-prosecutor-rights-espionage-arrested-bagirov/26515004.html|accessdate=25 August 2014|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|date=5 August 2014}}</ref> Arif Yunus was released due to poor health and was placed under guard and prohibited from leaving Baku.<ref name=index>{{cite web|title=Call for the immediate and unconditional release of Leyla Yunus, Arif Yunus and Rasul Jafarov|url=https://www.indexoncensorship.org/2014/08/call-immediate-unconditional-release-leyla-yunus-arif-yunus-rasul-jafarov/|publisher=Index on Censorship|date=6 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=hrwatch>{{cite web|title=Azerbaijan: Leading Rights Defender Arrested|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/08/05/azerbaijan-leading-rights-defender-arrested|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=5 August 2014}}</ref>
Arif Yunus was then detained and placed under detention on 5 August 2014. He has remained in detention since.<ref name=stability>{{cite web|title=Leyla Yunus|url=http://www.esiweb.org/index.php?lang=en&id=576|publisher=European Stability Initiative}}</ref> At times, during various trials, Arif Yunus has lost consciousness due to his health conditions.<ref name=awid1 />
On 13 August 2015 Arif Yunus was sentenced to 7 years in jail, and his wife, Leyla, was sentenced to 8.5 years in jail on charges that include fraud and tax evasion. The couple also face treason charges in a separate case. Western governments and human rights groups have expressed concern over their prosecution. [[Human Rights Watch]] has denounced their case as a show trial, and [[Amnesty International]] says the couple are [[prisoners of conscience]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Azerbaijan criticised for jailing activist couple|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/13/azerbaijan-criticised-for-jailing-activist-couple-leyla-arif-yunus|work=Guardian|date=13 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Groups Assail Sentencing of Azeri Rights Activist|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/groups-assail-sentencing-azeri-rights-activist/2916884.html|work=Voice of America|date=13 August 2015}}</ref>
==International condemnation== The detention of Arif and Leyla Yunus, as well as [[Rasul Jafarov]], has largely been regarded as another step in the state crackdown on civil society in Azerbaijan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/15/azerbaijan-detains-human-rights-activists-fresh-crackdown|title=Azerbaijan detains prominent human rights activists in fresh crackdown|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> The actions of the authorities have been harshly condemned by many prominent international human rights organizations, among them [[Amnesty International]] (which calls the Yunus "prisoners of conscience" and has called on the authorities to release them immediately),<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/eur55/012/2014/en/ Document - Azerbaijan: Leyla Yunus in failing health in prison]</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-EN.asp?newsid=5153&lang=2&cat=5|title=PACE: News|work=coe.int|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> [[United States Mission to the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|United States Mission to the OSCE]],<ref>[https://photos.state.gov/libraries/azerbaijan/749085/highlights/osce_Azerbaijan_Ongoing_Detentions.pdf United States Mission to the OSCE. Ongoing Detentions and Arrests of Peaceful Activists in Azerbaijan]</ref> Observatory for the Protection of Human Rights Defenders,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.omct.org/human-rights-defenders/urgent-interventions/azerbaijan/2014/07/d22777/|title=Azerbaijan: Prominent human rights defender Leyla Yunus, IPD Director and a member of OMCT General Assembly, sentenced to three months pre-trial detention|work=omct.org|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> [[Nobel Women's Initiative]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelwomensinitiative.org/2014/08/nobel-women-release-human-rights-activist-leyla-yunus/|title=Nobel Women: Release human rights activist Leyla Yunus|work=nobelwomensinitiative.org|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> [[Reporters Without Borders]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/azerbaijan-repression-unleashed-against-18-08-2014,46812.html|title=Repression unleashed against information freedom defenders - Reporters Without Borders|work=rsf.org|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/08/05/azerbaijan-leading-rights-defender-arrested-0|title=Azerbaijan: Leading Rights Defender Arrested|work=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> and others.
[[Human Rights Watch]] has called for the suspension of Azerbaijan's membership from an Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) because of "Azerbaijan government’s offensive against human rights defenders and non-governmental organizations".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/08/14/azerbaijan-transparency-group-should-suspend-membership|title=Azerbaijan: Transparency Group Should Suspend Membership|work=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Arif Yunus is married to Leyla Yunus. They have one daughter named Dinara.<ref name=guardian />
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

<!--This article is in US English--> {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Augustus Le Plongeon | image = Augustus-le-plongeon-photo.jpeg | caption = Photograph by [[Alice Dixon Le Plongeon]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1826|5|4|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Island of Jersey]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1908|12|13|1825|5|4|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City|New York]], [[United States]] | occupation = [[antiquarian]] and amateur [[archaeologist]] | nationality = [[United Kingdom]] | subject = [[Maya civilization]], [[Atlantis]] | imagesize = 200px }}
'''Augustus Le Plongeon''' (May 4, 1826 – December 13, 1908) was a French-American photographer, amateur archeologist, antiquarian and author who studied the [[pre-Columbian]] ruins of America, particularly those of the [[Maya civilization]] on the northern [[Yucatán Peninsula]]. While his writings contain many controversial notions that were not well received by his contemporaries and were later disproven, Le Plongeon left a lasting legacy in his photographs documenting the ancient ruins. He should also be regarded as one of the earliest proponents of [[Mayanism]].
== Early life and careers == Le Plongeon was born on the island of [[Jersey]] on May 4, 1826.<ref name="Desmond-2011">Desmond (2011)</ref> At 19, he sailed to South America and shipwrecked off the coast of [[Chile]]. While there he settled in [[Valparaiso]] and taught mathematics, drawing, and languages at a local college. In 1849 he sailed to [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]] during the [[California gold rush]] to work as a [[Surveyor (surveying)|surveyor]], and also apprenticed to become a doctor of medicine. One of his accomplishments as a surveyor included drawing a plan for the layout of the town of [[Marysville, California]] in the [[California Central Valley|Central Valley]] in 1851. Augustus was paid for his services as a surveyor with land deeds. He profited from the sale of these plots and this income would fund the majority of his archeological expeditions.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=A Dream of Maya|last=Desmond, Lawrence |author2=Messenger, Phyllis|first=|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|year=1988|isbn=0-8263-1000-1|location=Albuquerque|pages=}}</ref>
Le Plongeon traveled to England and saw a demonstration for new photographic processes at [[The Great Exhibition]]. He then stayed in England to study photography under [[William Fox Talbot]].<ref name=":0" /> Augustus wanted to test these methods in tropical climates so he spent time traveling to St. Thomas, Virgin Islands as well as Mexico, Australia, China, and the Pacific Islands. He returned to San Francisco to open a [[daguerreotype]] portrait studio on Clay Street. In 1862, he traveled to [[Lima, Peru]] and opened another photography studio and an "electro-hydropathic" medical clinic based on an early form of alternative medicine.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://archives2.getty.edu:8082/xtf/view?docId=ead/2004.M.18/2004.M.18.xml;chunk.id=ref15;brand=default|title=Finding Aid for Augustus and Alice Dixon Le Plongeon Papers|last=Guynn|first=Beth Ann|date=|website=|publisher=Getty Research Institute|access-date=}}</ref>
== Travels in Peru == Le Plongeon pioneered the use of photography as a tool for his studies. He began using the wet [[collodion]] glass-plate [[negative (photography)|negative]] process he used for studio portraits to record his explorations. He traveled extensively all over Peru for eight years visiting and photographing ancient ruins, including [[Tiwanaku|Tiahuanaco]]. Augustus also joined a number of [[E. G. Squier]]'s expeditions and took photographs out in the field. Le Plongeon was influenced by the work of [[Charles Étienne Brasseur de Bourbourg]], [[John Lloyd Stephens]], and [[Frederick Catherwood]]. These works, in combination with his own explorations in Peru, led Le Plongeon to believe that civilization had its origins in the New World.<ref name=":0" />
While in Peru Augustus became interested in the causes of earthquakes. He was able to observe the [[1868 Arica earthquake]] and he studied the resulting damage and interviewed people about what they experienced.<ref name=":0" /> During this time Le Plongeon began to speak out against abuses by Jesuit priests and the Catholic Church in Peru. He published two anti-Jesuit books, ''La religion de Jesus comparada con las ensenanzas de la Iglesia'' (1867), and ''Los Jesuitas y el Peru'' (1869).<ref name=":1" />
In 1870, he left Peru and traveled back once again to San Francisco where he gave a number of illustrated lectures at the [[California Academy of Sciences]] on Peruvian archaeology and the causes of earthquakes. His travels then continued on to [[New York City|New York]], and by 1871 he was at the [[British Museum]] in London studying [[Mesoamerica]]n [[manuscript]]s.<ref name=":0" /><nowiki/>
== Alice Dixon Le Plongeon == [[File:Alice Dixon LePlongeon Portrait.jpeg|thumb|Portrait of [[Alice Dixon Le Plongeon|Alice Dixon]], taken by her husband, Augustus]]
While in [[London]] he met [[Alice Dixon Le Plongeon|Alice Dixon]], the woman with whom he would collaborate for the rest of his life. Alice was born in London in 1851. Her father, Henry Dixon, was recognized in the late nineteenth century for his contribution to the development of [[panchromatic]] photography, and for his photos of London architecture taken for the [[Society for Photographing Relics of Old London]]. Alice learned the techniques of photography from her father and worked as an assistant in his studio. After meeting Augustus, she became interested in ancient American civilizations and studied John L. Stephen's ''Incidents of Travel in Yucatan.'' She agreed to accompany Augustus on an archaeology expedition to study Maya ruins in Mexico. The pair left for New York to finalize preparations for the trip. They married in New York before traveling to Mexico in 1873.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Yucatan Through Her Eyes: Alice Dixon Le Plongeon, Writer & Expeditionary Photographer|last=Desmond|first=Lawrence|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|year=2009|isbn=978-0-8263-4595-0|location=Albuquerque|pages=}}</ref>
== Travels in Yucatán == In 1873, the Le Plongeons traveled to Yucatán to study ancient Maya sites. Their goal was to explore the possibility of links between the Maya and the civilizations of ancient Egypt and Atlantis. Their first stop was in [[Mérida, Yucatán|Mérida]] and they stayed there while Alice recovered from [[yellow fever]]. During her recuperation, the couple made connections with local scholars and both Augustus and Alice learned to speak [[Yucatec Maya language|Yucatec Maya.]]<ref name=":2" /> After Alice had recovered, the Le Plongeons made a short excursion to [[Uxmal]].
The Le Plongeons were in Yucatán during the [[Caste War of Yucatán|Caste War]] – a conflict between the Maya, called the Chan Santa Cruz, and the army of Yucatán. When they traveled to Chicen Itza in 1875, they were accompanied by a military escort. When they arrived at the site, local Maya men were hired to clear the vegetation and help with excavations.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Yucatan Through Her Eyes|last=Desmond|first=Lawrence|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|year=2009|isbn=|location=Albuquerque|pages=}}</ref>
The Le Plongeons were some of the first people to photograph and study Chicen Itza. Their photographic work was methodical and systematic, and they took hundreds of [[stereoscopy|3-D photos]]. They documented entire Maya buildings such as the "Governor's Palace" at [[Uxmal]] in overlapping photos by placing the camera on a tall tripod or scaffold to correct for perspective, and then processed the plates in the unlit rooms of Maya buildings. In addition to entire facades of buildings, they also photographed small [[artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]], and architectural details such as [[bas-relief]]s, [[Maya script|Maya hieroglyphic]] inscriptions, and [[sculpture]]s. They excavated buildings, drew maps and copied murals, and made molds of bas-reliefs.<ref name=":0" />
[[File:Chac Mool1.jpg|thumb|left|[[Chacmool]] statue from the [[Chichen Itza]] site]] At [[Chichen Itza]] they excavated a structure known as the Platform of the Eagles and Jaguars and unearthed a large statue or altar figurine. They coined the name "Chaacmol" (later "[[Chac Mool]]" or ''chacmool'') for it. Although their derivation of the name is known now to have had no association with figures of this type, the name has remained in general use among later archaeologists. This statue would later be used as a demonstration of [[Toltec]] influences at the site, with other examples found at the Toltec capital, [[Tula (Mesoamerican site)|Tula]]. They also documented their excavation of the Platform of Venus with photos as well as plan and cross-section drawings.
From 1873–1884 the Le Plongeons visited and photographed other Maya sites such as [[Izamal]], [[Isla Mujeres]], [[Cozumel]], [[Cancún]], and [[Ake]], and traveled to [[Belize]] (British Honduras). During this time they made a few trips back to New York to attempt to sell bas-relief molds to museums, give lectures, and solicit financial backing for their studies.<ref name=":2" /> {{-}}
== Theories == By the 1880s, while most [[Mayanist]]s accepted that the Maya civilization postdated [[Ancient Egypt]], Le Plongeon stood by his theories. He cited his years of fieldwork and studies of archival sources, and challenged those he considered "armchair" archaeologists to debate the issues. But as evidence mounted against [[cultural diffusion]], Le Plongeon became marginalized and his theories falling further outside the growing mainstream of Maya archaeology.<ref name="Desmond-2011" />
Le Plongeon insisted that the symbols of [[Freemasonry]] could be traced to the ancient Maya, and that this ancient knowledge had come to ancient Egypt from the ancient Maya by way of Atlantis. He and Alice constructed an imaginative "history", with the Maya sites in Yucatán being the cradle of [[civilization]], with civilization then traveling east first to [[Atlantis]] and later to [[Ancient Egypt]]. The Le Plongeons named kings and queens of these dynasties, and said that various artworks were portraits of such ancient royalty (such as the famous [[Chacmool]], which the couple excavated at Chichén Itzá). The Le Plongeons reconstructed a detailed but fanciful story of Queen Moo and Prince Coh (also known as "Chac Mool") in which Prince Coh's death resulted in the erection of monuments in his honor (similar to the commemoration of [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]] by [[Queen Victoria]]).<ref name=":0" />
== Later Career and Legacy == While most of Le Plongeon's contemporaries dismissed his theories, individuals such as [[Ignatius L. Donnelly]] and [[Helena Blavatsky]] drew upon Le Plongeon's research for their own theories. Augustus spent the remainder of his life in [[Brooklyn, New York]], writing about the connections between Maya and Egypt and defending himself against detractors. Augustus le Plongeon died in Brooklyn in 1908 at the age of eighty-three; Alice followed in 1910 at the age of fifty-nine.
A collection of the works of the Le Plongeons currently resides at the [[Getty Center|Getty Research Institute]] in [[Los Angeles]]. The archive contains original records covering their travels from the 1860s through the early 1900s, including diaries, unpublished scholarly manuscripts and notes, correspondence, and extensive photographic documentation of ancient architecture and sculpture, city views, and ethnographic studies.
Le Plongeon was elected a member of the [[American Antiquarian Society]] in 1878.<ref>[http://www.americanantiquarian.org/memberlistl American Antiquarian Society Members Directory]</ref>

= [[File:Carl Christian Reindorf.png]] | caption = Carl Christian Reindorf | birth_name = Carl Christian Reindorf | birth_date = {{birth date|1834|05|31|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Accra, Ghana|Accra, Gold Coast]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1917|7|1|1834|05|31}} | death_place = [[Accra, Ghana|Accra, Gold Coast]] | occupation = {{hlist|[[Historian]]|[[Minister (Christianity)|Minister]]}} | language = {{hlist|[[English language|English]]|[[Ga language]]}} | nationality = [[British nationality law|British subject]] | education = [[Basel Mission]] | genre = | movement = | spouse = Juliana Ayikai Mansah Djebi (m. 1856) | signature = | website = | imagesize = | nickname = | influences = | influenced = | ethnicity = }} '''Carl Christian Reindorf''' (31 May 1834 – 1 July 1917)<ref name=DACB /> was a [[Gold Coast Euro-Africans|Euro-African]]-born pioneer [[historian]], [[teacher]], [[farmer]], [[Commerce|trader]], [[physician]] and [[pastor]] who worked with the [[Basel Mission]] on the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.internationalbulletin.org/issues/2009-02/2009-02-065-hauser-renner.html|title="Obstinate" Pastor and Pioneer Historian: The Impact of Basel Mission Ideology on the Thought of Carl Christian Reindorf|website=www.internationalbulletin.org|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> He wrote ''The History of the Gold Coast and Asante'' in the [[Ga language]], considered a pioneering work.<ref name="JenkinsDACB">{{cite encyclopedia|first=Paul |last=Jenkins |title=Reindorf, Carl Christian |work=Dictionary of African Christian Biography |edition=online |url=http://www.dacb.org/stories/ghana/reindorf2_carl.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150410233854/http://www.dacb.org/stories/ghana/reindorf2_carl.html |archivedate=10 April 2015 }}</ref> The work was later translated into English and published in 1895 in [[Switzerland]].<ref name=DACB /> He used written sources and [[oral tradition]], interviewing more than 200 people in the course of assembling his history.<ref name=JenkinsDACB />
==Biography== <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[File:CCReindorf1.jpg|left|thumb|Reverend Carl Christian Reindorf]] --> === Early life and education ===
Reindorf was born in [[Prampram]], [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]], a palm oil trading port<ref name="DACB" /><ref name=":4" /> He was the only son of Carl Christian Reindorf Hackenburg (1806 - 1865), a soldier of half-[[Danish people|Danish]] heritage, and Hannah Anowah Ama Cudjoe Reindorf (1811 -1902), an ethnic [[Ga people|Ga]] from Kinka, Dutch Accra.<ref name="DACB">{{cite encyclopedia|title=Carl Christian Reindorf|url=https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/reindorf-carl/|accessdate=9 January 2012|last=Ofosu-Appiah|first=L. H.|date=|edition=online|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708195917/http://dacb.org/stories/ghana/reindorf3_carl.html|archivedate=8 July 2016|deadurl=no|work=Dictionary of African Christian Biography}}</ref><ref name=":4" /> Carl Reindorf's father worked as a soldier at the Osu Danish garrison before he became a local agent for an English merchant, Joshua Ridley who eventually married the older Reindorf's sister, Anna.<ref name=":4" /> Reindorf's grandfather, Augustus Frederick Hackenburg was a Danish merchant who came to the Gold Coast in 1739 and later became the colonial Governor, leaving the position in 1748.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H4BEgpRd0VwC&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq=carl+christian+reindorf+gold+coast+wife&source=bl&ots=H95HzIhCXU&sig=ymYfWvkwcQO554VQeJb_ZplTLLA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixpZv-4pLbAhXCuVMKHb9sD8UQ6AEIbjAQ#v=onepage&q=carl%20christian%20reindorf%20gold%20coast%20wife&f=false|title=Carl Christian Reindorf: Colonial Subjectivity and Drawn Boundaries|last=Quartey|first=Seth|date=March 2006|publisher=Lulu.com|year=|isbn=9781411677708|location=|pages=|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180519222420/https://books.google.com/books?id=H4BEgpRd0VwC&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq=carl+christian+reindorf+gold+coast+wife&source=bl&ots=H95HzIhCXU&sig=ymYfWvkwcQO554VQeJb_ZplTLLA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixpZv-4pLbAhXCuVMKHb9sD8UQ6AEIbjAQ#v=onepage&q=carl%20christian%20reindorf%20gold%20coast%20wife&f=false|archivedate=19 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As a little child, he lived in [[ritual servitude]] at a fetish shrine, ''Digbla'' of ''Gbugla'' of his mother's Ga-Dangme traditional religion.<ref name="DACB" /> After fleeing the shrine, he received his early education at the [[Danish language]] school at the [[Osu Castle|Christiansborg Castle]] from 1842 to 1847.<ref name="DACB" /><ref name=":0" /> His schoolmates were the Hesse sisters: [[Alexander Worthy Clerk#Personal life and ancestry|Pauline Hesse]], a trader and missionary-wife, married to the Jamaican Moravian educator, [[Alexander Worthy Clerk]] (1820 ─ 1906), in addition to [[Regina Hesse]] (1832 ─ 1898), a pioneer educator and school principal who married Hermann Ludwig Rottmann, the first Basel missionary-trader and founder of the [[Basel Mission]] Trading Company in Christiansborg, Gold Coast.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":40">{{Cite journal|last=Kwakye|first=Abraham Nana Opare|date=2018|title=Returning African Christians in Mission to the Gold Coast|url=https://www.euppublishing.com/doi/pdfplus/10.3366/swc.2018.0203|journal=Studies in World Christianity|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|volume=24|issue=1|pages=25-45|via=}}</ref> He then continued his education at the [[Salem School, Osu|Basel Mission School]] at [[Osu, Accra|Osu]] between 1847 and 1855.<ref name="DACB" /><ref name=":0" /> He was baptised in 1844.<ref name="DACB" /> Unhappy with the school curriculum, he quit school halfway through his education and worked for his uncle as a trader for two years from 1850 to 1852.<ref name=":0" /> During this period, he often crossed the [[Volta River]] to trade with the [[Ewe people]].<ref name="DACB" /> One of his tutors in [[catechism]] was the German [[Philology|philologist]], [[Johannes Zimmermann]] (1825–1876) who had a strong influence on him in the areas of [[source criticism]] and [[historiography]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zjD5z4Qan6sC&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Recovery of the West African Past: African Pastors and African History in the Nineteenth Century : C.C. Reindorf & Samuel Johnson : Papers from an International Seminar Held in Basel, Switzerland, 25-28th October 1995 to Celebrate the Centenary of the Publication of C.C. Reindorf's History of the Gold Coast and Asante|last=Jenkins|first=Paul|date=1998|publisher=Basler Afrika Bibliographien|isbn=9783905141702|language=en}}</ref>
=== Christian mission ===
Carl Reindorf was a mission assistant to the Basel missionary, August Steinhauser and ran administrative errands for him in [[Odumase Krobo|Odumase-Krobo]] to meet the paramount chief, Odonkor Azu, whose sons, including Sir Emmanuel Mate Kole, were educated by the Basel Mission.<ref name="DACB" /> Reindorf succeeded Steinhauser at [[Abokobi]] as a missionary, following the 1854 bombardment of Christiansborg by the British [[naval ship]] ''H. M. S.'' ''Scourge,'' after the poll tax riots'','' compelling the mission to move from Osu to [[Abokobi]].<ref name="DACB" /> The local Abokobi shaman, ''Akoto Badu'' of ''Agbowo'', converted to Christianity while he was stationed there.<ref name="DACB" /> He was transferred to [[Krobo Odumase|Krobo]] in 1859 to deputise [[Johannes Zimmermann]].<ref name="DACB" /> He was also missionary at [[Teshie]] but was unable to win any Christian converts.<ref name="DACB" /> Reindorf was consecrated a full-time catechist in 1857.<ref name="DACB" /> In 1869, he was elected a [[presbyter]] and assistant superintendent of the ''Christiansborg Church'', now the [[Ebenezer Presbyterian Church, Osu]].<ref name="DACB" /> On 13 October 1872 he was ordained a minister of the Basel mission.<ref name="DACB" /><ref name=":0" />
=== Role as a physician and farmer ===
Given his knowledge of traditional healing through [[Herbalism|herbal medicine]], gleaned from travels around the Gold Coast, Reindorf acted as the [[physician]] and [[surgeon]] to the wounded soldiers during an 1870 local war between the [[Ga-Adangbe people|Ga]] and [[Akwamu]] peoples. <ref name="DACB" /> Four years earlier, he had performed a similar medical role in 1866 local war between the Dangmes of Ada and the Awuna Ewe people.<ref name="DACB" /> In appreciation of his medical services in treating the wounded after the Ga-Akwamu war, he was the recipient of a citation of commendation from the Administrator (1867-1872) and later Governor (1879 -1880), H. T. Ussher during the welcome ceremonies for a visiting contingent from [[Lagos|Lagos, Nigeria]].<ref name="DACB" />
He also engaged in large-scale coffee farming at a place he named "[[Hebron]]" near the hamlet of Adenkrebi close to [[Aburi]]. <ref name="DACB" />
=== Teaching and writing ===
Reindorf taught as an assistant teacher of history at the [[Presbyterian College of Education, Akropong|Basel Mission Seminary]] at [[Akropong]] from November 1860 to April 1862. Other courses at the seminary included [[English language|English]], [[Biblical exegesis]], [[Christian theology|theology]], [[geography]] and [[Classical language|classical languages]].<ref name=":0" /> He was the [[Head teacher|headmaster]] of the all boys' middle boarding school, the ''[[Salem School, Osu|Salem School]]'' at [[Osu, Accra|Osu]] in 1873.<ref name="DACB" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.osusalem.org/pages/heads.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706182955/http://www.osusalem.org/pages/heads.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2017-07-06|title=Presbyterian Boys Boarding School, Osu Salem|website=www.osusalem.org|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref> As principal, he mentored several students such as Christian Holm, Peter M. Anteson and William A. Quartey, who all became teachers and catechists of the Basel mission.<ref name=":0" /> Carl Reindorf taught literacy in the [[Ga language]] and composed church hymns in Ga in 1856 and 1857.<ref name="DACB" /> He established a boarding school at Mayera with a dozen Ga boys from Accra.<ref name="DACB" /> He lived and worked in Mayera for a decade before returning to Christiansborg, Osu.<ref name="DACB" /> In 1903, he was part of the committee at [[Abokobi]] that revised the Ga Bible, including Ludwig Richter, Jakob Wilhelm Werz, Christian Kölle and Daniel Saba.<ref name=":0" /> The revision committee completed its work in 1912.<ref name="DACB" />
He finished work on his notable book, ''A History of the Gold Coast and Asante'' in 1889.<ref name="DACB" /> This literary piece was originally written in the [[Ga language]].<ref name="DACB" /><ref name=":0" /> The English translation of the book was published in [[Basel]] in 1895.<ref name="DACB" /> The inspiration or impetus for his [[Masterpiece|magnum opus]] came from a strong sense of nationalism and the linguistic work that had been carried out on Twi oral traditions by the German philologist and fellow Basel missionary, [[Johann Gottlieb Christaller]] (1827–1895).<ref name="DACB" /><ref name=":0" /> Reindorf was also likely influenced by [[Christian Jacob Protten]] (1715–1769), a fellow Ga-Danish mulatto or [[Gold Coast Euro-Africans|Gold Coast Euro-African]] and a 17th-century Moravian missionary and educator in Christiansborg who wrote the first recorded grammatical pamphlet in the [[Ga language|Ga]] and [[Fante language|Fante]] languages, which was published in [[Copenhagen]] in 1764.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/protten-cj/|title=Christian Jacob Protten|last=Smith|first=Noel|date=|website=dacb.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref><ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=https://dacb.org/stories/ghana/protten-chrisjacob/|title=Christian Jacob Protten|last=Dreydoppel|first=Otto|date=|website=dacb.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref><ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Sebald|first=Peter|date=1994|title=Christian Jacob Protten Africanus (1715-1769) - erster Missionar einer deutschen Missionsgesellschaft in Schwarzafrika|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/christian-jacob-protten-africanus-1715-1769-erster-missionar-einer-deutschen-missionsgesellschaft-in-schwarzafrika/oclc/610701345&referer=brief_results|journal=Kolonien und Missionen.|language=German|pages=109–121}}</ref><ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|last=Simonsen|first=Gunvor|date=April 2015|title=Belonging in Africa: Frederik Svane and Christian Protten on the Gold Coast in the Eighteenth Century|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/itinerario/article/belonging-in-africa-frederik-svane-and-christian-protten-on-the-gold-coast-in-the-eighteenth-century/FD50A3811C421A5A91D9B1E2F7613BEA|dead-url=no|journal=Itinerario|language=en|volume=39|issue=1|pages=91–115|doi=10.1017/S0165115315000145|issn=0165-1153|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180618045639/https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/itinerario/article/belonging-in-africa-frederik-svane-and-christian-protten-on-the-gold-coast-in-the-eighteenth-century/FD50A3811C421A5A91D9B1E2F7613BEA|archive-date=18 June 2018|access-date=14 October 2018|via=|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=A History of Moravian Missions|last=Hutton|first=J. E.|publisher=|year=1923|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Christian-Jakobus-Protten/6000000016682022141|title=Christian Jakobus Protten|website=geni_family_tree|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-14}}</ref><ref name=":42">{{Cite book|title="En nyttig Grammaticalsk Indledelse til Tvende hidintil gandske ubekiendte Sprog, Fanteisk og Acraisk,"|last=Protten|first=Christian Jacob|publisher=|year=1764|isbn=|location=Copenhagen|pages=}}</ref>
== Personal life == In 1856, Carl Reindorf married Juliana Ayikai Mansah Djebi from a notable household in ''Asere''.<ref name="DACB" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a5loknGzxTQC&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=Ayikai+Mansah+Djebi&source=bl&ots=MfKm_fYSVz&sig=jN7-r0tGFlWV3626CuaMb_3Dztw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFoZvX55LbAhWO3VMKHefaAnAQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Ayikai%20Mansah%20Djebi&f=false|title=Encounters in Quest of Christian Womanhood: The Basel Mission in Pre- and Early Colonial Ghana|last=Sill|first=Ulrike|date=2010|publisher=BRILL|year=|isbn=9004188886|location=|pages=157|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180519222420/https://books.google.com/books?id=a5loknGzxTQC&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=Ayikai+Mansah+Djebi&source=bl&ots=MfKm_fYSVz&sig=jN7-r0tGFlWV3626CuaMb_3Dztw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFoZvX55LbAhWO3VMKHefaAnAQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Ayikai%20Mansah%20Djebi&f=false|archivedate=19 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Djebi had received a European-type education, living with Marie Locher, a missionary-wife in Christiansborg. <ref name=":3" /> The couple had eleven children including a prominent Gold Coast physician and a 1910 medical graduate of the [[Durham University]], Dr. Charles Elias Reindorf, who passed away in 1968.<ref name="DACB" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tetty|first=Charles|date=1985|title=Medical Practitioners of African Descent in Colonial Ghana|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/217977|journal=The International Journal of African Historical Studies|volume=18|issue=1|pages=139–144|doi=10.2307/217977|access-date=13 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180309150307/http://www.jstor.org/stable/217977|archive-date=9 March 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Works== *'''Reindorf, Carl Christian''' (1895, 1966), ''The History of the Gold Coast and Asante,'' Basel <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bzNGAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+History+of+the+Gold+Coast+and+Asante&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwij6_Dvw__dAhWpVN8KHbQFBGcQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=The%20History%20of%20the%20Gold%20Coast%20and%20Asante&f=false|title=History of the Gold Coast and Asante, Based on Traditions and Historical Facts: Comprising a Period of More Than Three Centuries from about 1500 to 1860|last=Reindorf|first=Carl Christian|date=1895|publisher=The author|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QvYNswEACAAJ&dq=The+History+of+the+Gold+Coast+and+Asante&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwij6_Dvw__dAhWpVN8KHbQFBGcQ6AEILTAB|title=History of the Gold Coast and Asante (Classic Reprint)|last=Reindorf|first=Carl Christian|date=2018-04-21|publisher=LULU Press|isbn=9781330819852|language=en}}</ref>
== Death and legacy == Carl Reindorf died of [[Death by natural causes|natural causes]] on 1 July 1917.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="JenkinsDACB" /> The chiefs and people of Osu accorded him a ''"full state funeral"'' with ''"the attendance reported as being the largest seen in Accra for many years"'' <ref name=":4" /> At the church service, six [[Basel Mission]] pastors, including his fellow native Ga ministers, Engmann, Quartey, Richter and Wuta Ofei delivered eulogies.<ref name=":4" /> His remains were buried at the [[List of cemeteries in Accra|Basel Mission Cemetery]] in Accra and his epitaph reads, ''"native pastor and historian"''.<ref name=":4" /> A commemorative plaque in the sanctuary of the [[Ebenezer Presbyterian Church, Osu]] was dedicated in his memory.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://osueben-ezer.com/churchhall|title=Osu Eben-ezer Presbyterian Church {{!}} Church Hall|last=Innovation|first=Osis|website=osueben-ezer.com|access-date=2017-12-08|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171208143043/http://osueben-ezer.com/churchhall|archivedate=8 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The church also renamed its chapel extension, the ''Carl Christian Reindorf Auditorium'' in recognition of his contributions to church, history and country.<ref name=":2" />

16 January 2017) was an Australian historian, unionist and activist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nteu.org.au/myunion/scholarships/carolyn_allport |title=Carolyn Allport – National Tertiary Education Union |publisher=Nteu.org.au |date= |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tributes.smh.com.au/obituaries/smh-au/obituary.aspx?n=carolyn-allport&pid=183685165 |title=Carolyn ALLPORT Death Notice – Sydney, New South Wales | The Sydney Morning Herald |publisher=Tributes.smh.com.au |date= |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/higher-education/agenda-bender-calls-it-a-day/news-story/88ab1217a23c433a4ffd2cb765bb635d |title=Agenda bender calls it a day |publisher=The Australian |date= |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2009/09/stop-s17.html |title=Australia: University staff strike for "day of action" – World Socialist Web Site |publisher=Wsws.org |date= |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref>
Allport was an academic at [[Macquarie University]] for more than twenty years.
Allport was National President of the [[National Tertiary Education Union]] from 1994 to 2010 and on the executive of the [[Australian Council of Trade Unions]] for some of that time. She represented the NTEU at [[OECD]] and [[UNESCO]] fora.

{{Infobox company | name = Clinique Laboratories, LLC | logo = Logo Clinique.jpg | logo_size = 250 | type = Division of holding company | foundation = 1968 | founder = [[Evelyn Lauder]] | location = [[New York City]] | industry = [[Consumer goods]] | parent = [[Estée Lauder Companies]]
(1968–present) | products = [[Cosmetics]] | homepage = [http://www.clinique.com/ clinique.com] }} '''Clinique Laboratories, [[Limited liability company|LLC]]''' ({{IPAc-en|k|l|ᵻ|ˈ|n|iː|k}}) is an [[United States|American]] manufacturer of skincare, cosmetics, toiletries and fragrances, usually sold in high end department stores. It is a subsidiary of the [[Estée Lauder Companies]]. ==History== [[File:Clinique Farmers Dunedin 2013.jpg|thumb|Clinique counter at a [[Farmers Trading Company|Farmers]] [[department store]]]] In 1967, American [[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]] magazine published an article called “''Can Great Skin Be Created''?”, written by beauty editor Carol Phillips with [[Norman Orentreich]], discussing the significance of a skin-care routine. Evelyn Lauder, daughter-in-law of Estée Lauder, read the article,{{cite web|url=http://skinbody.glam.com/topics/beauty_brands/clinique/ |title=Mode Glam |publisher=Skinbody.glam.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-17}} and brought it to Estée’s attention. Both Carol Phillips and Orentreich were recruited to help create the brand, and in August, 1968, Clinique premiered as the world’s first allergy tested, dermatologist-driven line at [[Saks Fifth Avenue]] in the UK.{{cite web|author=Rita Silvan |url=http://www.ellecanada.com/beauty/clinique-c-est-chic/a/24346 |title=Clinique, c'est chic. |publisher=Elle Canada |date=2005-03-10 |accessdate=2015-07-17}} [[Evelyn Lauder]], an executive at Estée Lauder and member of the Lauder family, created the Clinique [[brand name]] and developed its line of products.{{cite news |first=Michelle |last=Dargan |title=Service to be Monday for Evelyn Lauder, beauty exec and pink ribbon co-creator |url=http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/news/service-to-be-monday-for-evelyn-lauder-beauty-1966283.html |work=[[Palm Beach Daily News]] |publisher= |date=2011-11-13 |accessdate=2011-11-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513210413/http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/news/service-to-be-monday-for-evelyn-lauder-beauty-1966283.html |archivedate=2012-05-13 |df= }} Lauder worked as the training director for Clinique. She was the first person to wear the trademark white [[lab coat]], now worn by Clinique Consultants worldwide. Clinique was the third brand that was "born" from the Lauder Group after Estée Lauder and Aramis. In 2008, Clinique announced a partnership[http://www.cliniquemedical.com/press.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531053446/http://www.cliniquemedical.com/press.html |date=May 31, 2009 }} with [[Allergan]], the maker of Botox and former [[cosmeceutical]] partner of [[Elizabeth Arden]], with the result being a new line called Clinique Medical. The line is only available in physician's offices. The 5-product set is designed for pre- and post-operation skin care, and targets complications such as redness, tightness, burning, irritation, discoloration, among others that "slow the healing process."[http://www.cliniquemedical.com/prof_optimizingRegimen.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903054238/http://www.cliniquemedical.com/prof_optimizingRegimen.html |date=September 3, 2009 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category-inline|Clinique Laboratories, LLC}} * [http://www.clinique.com Clinique's Official International Website] {{Estée Lauder Companies |state=expanded}} {{cosmetics}} [[Category:Cosmetics brands]] [[Category:Cosmetics companies of the United States]] [[Category:History of cosmetics]] [[Category:Estée Lauder Companies]]

'''Comédie du Cap''' was a theater in [[Cap-Français]] in [[Saint-Domingue]], active from 1740 to 1793; from 1764 as a public theater. It is regarded as a prototype for the theaters in Saint-Domingue, were theater were immensely popular.
==History== The Comédie du Cap was opened in 1740 as a private theater at Rue Vaudreuil, were [[amateur theater]] were performed for only the aristocracy personally acquainted to the amateur actors.<ref>Lauren R. Clay: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vg_oFcPJxucC&printsec=frontcover&dq=lauren+clay+saint+domingue&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiy6rjd26_VAhVFCpoKHQeOBIAQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Stagestruck: The Business of Theater in Eighteenth-Century France and Its colonies]''</ref>
In 1764, it became a public institution, and a new building was inaugurated in 1765. This was the result of the wish of the government of France to show favor to their Caribbean colonies after their loss of French Canada during the [[Seven Years' War]], and the theater was given great government support as a tool for representation of the French crown: in 1775, it was given direct financial support from the government during a period of economic crisis.<ref>Lauren R. Clay: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vg_oFcPJxucC&printsec=frontcover&dq=lauren+clay+saint+domingue&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiy6rjd26_VAhVFCpoKHQeOBIAQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Stagestruck: The Business of Theater in Eighteenth-Century France and Its colonies]''</ref>
The theater had a seat for 1500 people, and a staff of twelve male and eight female actors. It hosted about 2000 plays, operas and concerts each year and public balls twice a weeks, and it was also rented for private functions.
Theater was very popular in the colony, and the Comedie du Cap was one of the city's most prominent places of social life. As it was regularly visited by the same people, it was necessary to continually offer new performances, and the theater had a good reputation of offering the latest plays from Paris.<ref>Lauren R. Clay: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vg_oFcPJxucC&printsec=frontcover&dq=lauren+clay+saint+domingue&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiy6rjd26_VAhVFCpoKHQeOBIAQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Stagestruck: The Business of Theater in Eighteenth-Century France and Its colonies]''</ref>
Because of its remoteness and the bad reputation of the Caribbean colonies in 18th-century France, it was difficult to engage performers from France: it was therefore necessary to offer very high salaries to the professional performers engaged from France, but they were normally not willing to stay long.<ref>Lauren R. Clay: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vg_oFcPJxucC&printsec=frontcover&dq=lauren+clay+saint+domingue&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiy6rjd26_VAhVFCpoKHQeOBIAQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Stagestruck: The Business of Theater in Eighteenth-Century France and Its colonies]''</ref> It was however quite common for actors from France to tour in the colonies; the most famed occasion being the Parisian star Louis-Francois Ribie, who performed with a troupe composed of Parisian actors in Saint Domingue and Martinique in 1787-88 and 1791.<ref>Lauren R. Clay: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vg_oFcPJxucC&printsec=frontcover&dq=lauren+clay+saint+domingue&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiy6rjd26_VAhVFCpoKHQeOBIAQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Stagestruck: The Business of Theater in Eighteenth-Century France and Its colonies]''</ref>
Initially closed for non-whites, it opened for all races in 1775, though the seats were segregated: the racial organisation of the theater has been referred to as a representation of the racial segregation of the entire colony. The theater was very popular among all classes and also affordable for most.
===Destruction=== The Comédie du Cap was likely destroyed during the [[Pillage of Cap-Français]] in June 1793.

McClellan III: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=tIxDYmc0c3YC&pg=PA1095&lpg=PA1095&dq=comedie+du+cap+1740&source=bl&ots=JDE_goI47v&sig=_6gUWkpoHDEpN1ATXOy2koyiBu4&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=uYOTVN28I6SaygPJiIG4Dw&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=comedie%20du%20cap%201740&f=false Colonialism and Science: Saint Domingue and the Old Regime]'' * John D. Garrigus: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8TzIAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA163&dq=first+theater+cap-francais&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=y4KTVKrID4GuygOV_IGQDw&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false Before Haiti: Race and Citizenship in French Saint-Domingue]'' * Jeremy D. Popkin: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=VSeLGtVm0iIC&pg=PA181&dq=first+theater+cap-francais&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=y4KTVKrID4GuygOV_IGQDw&ved=0CGEQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=first%20theater%20cap-francais&f=false Facing Racial Revolution: Eyewitness Accounts of the Haitian Insurrection]'' * John G. Cale, ''[https://digitalcommons.lsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3111&context=gradschool_disstheses French Secular Music in Saint-Domingue (1750-1795) Viewed as a Factor in America's Musical Growth]'', Louisiana State University and Agricultural & Mechanical College, 1971 * Jean Fouchard, ''Le Théâtre à Saint-Domingue'' (1955) * Jean Fouchard, ''Artistes et Répertoires des Scènes de Saint-Domingue'' (1955)

'''Corporate liberalism''' is a thesis in United States [[historiography]] in which the corporate elite become "both the chief beneficiaries of and the chief lobbyists for the supposedly anti-business regulations".<ref name=Long/> The idea is that both owners of corporations as well as high up government officials came together to become the class of elites. The elite class then conspires (or, less maliciously, the system motivates the elite) to keep power away from the low or middle class. Presumably, to avoid the risk of revolution from the poor and powerless and to avoid the realization of [[class conflict]], the elite have the working class pick sides in a mock conflict between business and state.<ref name=Long/><ref name=Oglesby/>
== Overview == Corporate liberalism's principal text is [[James Weinstein (author)|James Weinstein]]'s ''The Corporate Ideal in the Liberal State''.
{{quote box|align=right|width=40%| quoted=1 |quote = Corporate liberalism functions via a façade of opposition between a purportedly progressive statocracy and a purportedly pro-market plutocracy. The con operates by co-opting potential opponents of the establishment; those who recognise that something’s amiss with the statocratic wing are lured into supporting the plutocratic wing, and vice versa...Perhaps the balance of power shifts slightly toward one side or the other; but the system remains essentially unchanged. (Which explains, for example, why the recent much-trumpeted power shift in Congress has resulted in precious little policy change.)|source=—[[Roderick T. Long]]<ref name=Long/>}} [[Carl Oglesby]] describes corporate liberalism as a cooperation between those with the most military power and those with the most industrial power. Oglesby suggests that "corporate liberalism...performs for the corporate state a function quite like what the Church once performed for the feudal state. It seeks to justify its burdens and protect it from change".<ref name="Oglesby">[https://web.archive.org/web/20061011033218/http://www.radicaleducation.org/sds_documents/oglesby_future.html Let Us Shape the Future, November 27 1965, lecture by Carl Oglesby - SDS President - spoke at a March on Washington, Available at web.archive.org and accessed January 12 2013].</ref>
[[Roderick T. Long]] writes similarly that state and corporate power have a symbiotic relationship. Long writes about the alleged realizations of corporate liberalism during the 1960s, the realizations that the business class was hardly a "persecuted minority" and that the state hardly a "bulwark of the poor against the plutocracy".<ref name="Long">[http://aaeblog.com/2007/02/06/remembering-corporate-liberalism/ "Remembering Corporate Liberalism", Austro-Athenian Empire: Roderick's blog, posted February 6 2007, accessed January 12 2013].</ref>
Weinstein's idea of corporate liberalism should not be confused with [[Ellis W. Hawley]]'s use of the term ([[Daniel T. Rodgers]] noted that Hawley's use of "corporate liberalism" was more a description of [[liberal corporatism]] than anything else). It should not also be confused with the concepts developed by Martin J. Sklar, who invented the term "corporate liberalism" in an article on Woodrow Wilson first published in 1960 when he was in graduate school in history at the University of Wisconsin. Sklar published the essay in ''Studies on the Left'', where he and James Weinstein were co-editors. Sklar's writing about corporate liberalism was a major influence on Weinstein's thinking (which Weinstein himself acknowledged in the preface to his book, ''The Corporate Ideal in the Liberal State''). Arguing that the rise of the large corporation "as the dominant mode of business enterprise" was the result of a concerted effort by capitalists and like-minded political leaders and intellectuals, Sklar wrote that corporate liberalism was the "bourgeois Yankee cousin of modern European and English social democracy".
Sklar subsequently refined and developed the corporate liberal concept in a 1988 book, ''The Corporate Reconstruction of American Capitalism'', which significantly differed from Weinstein's interpretation. On pages 34–35, Sklar defined corporate liberalism as the ideology of the political movement that accomplished the corporate reconstruction of the United States political-economic order on the basis of a mutual adjustment between [[corporate capitalism]] and the [[Liberalism in the United States|American liberal tradition]]. In keeping with that tradition, corporate liberalism upheld the corporate administered market and the rise of regulatory government, but not a "corporate state" or a statist command system. Sklar did not see corporate liberalism as simply the ideology of corporate capitalists, but rather as a broad cross-class ideology "expressing the inter-relations of corporate capitalists, political leaders, intellectuals, proprietary capitalists, professionals, and reformers, workers and trade union leaders, populists, and socialists—all of those who could, to a greater or lesser extent, identify their outlook or their interest in administered markets and government regulation, with the rise, legitimation, and institutionalization of the corporate capitalist order".
According to Sklar’s account, corporate liberalism was not a monolithic ideology, but unfolded in several major political variants that there were at once "mutually complimentary and in conflict with one another". On the left, they were [[Theodore Roosevelt]]'s "statist-tending corporate liberalism"; on the center-left, [[Woodrow Wilson]]'s "regulatory corporate liberalism"; and on the center-right, [[William Howard Taft]]'s "minimalist regulatory corporate liberalism". Sklar contined saying: "It was from this three-way progressive split that sprang the major divisions of twentieth-century American politics with respect to political-economic policy formation".
Other historians who advocate similar theories of United States history include [[Gabriel Kolko]] and [[Murray Rothbard]]. The thesis of corporate liberalism has similarities with the ideas of the [[organizational synthesis]] school of [[Alfred D. Chandler Jr.]], [[Samuel P. Hays]], [[Robert Wiebe]] and [[Louis Galambos]].
== Notes == {{reflist}}
== References == * James Weinstein, ''The Corporate Ideal in the Liberal State.'' * Daniel T. Rodgers, "In Search of Progressivism." ''Reviews in American History'',December 1982. * Martin J. Sklar, ''The Corporate Reconstruction of American Capitalism, 1890-1916: The Market, The Law, and Politics'' (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1988). * ----------. "Woodrow Wilson and the Political-Economy of Modern United States Liberalism," ''Studies on the Left'', 1:3 (Fall 1960), reprinted in Martin J. Sklar, ''The United States as a Developing Country'' (Cambridge University Press, 1992), pp. 102–142.
