'''Strategic reset''' was a policy framework designed to stop counterproductive U.S. engagement in a fragmenting [[Iraq]] and to strengthen the [[United States]]' stance throughout the [[Middle East]]. In [[military]] terms, "reset" refers to "a series of actions to restore units to a desired level of combat capability commensurate with future mission requirements."<ref>[http://armedservices.house.gov/pdfs/joint013107/multi%20testimony013107.pdf "Readiness Committee Written Statement." Brigadier General Charles A. Anderson]</ref>
The proposal advocates harnessing U.S. military, economic, and diplomatic power to protect critical [[national security]] interests rather than expending this power in efforts to accommodate political progress amid multiple [[Sectarian violence in Iraq (2006–08)|internal]] and [[Iraq War|external]] conflicts in [[Iraq]]. The plan for strategic reset entails four key measures: *acknowledging Iraq's [[politics of Iraq|political]] and [[demography|demographic]] fragmentation *implementing prompt [[phased redeployment|phased military redeployment]] *establishing local and regional methods for improving security and [[diplomacy]] in the Middle East *developing a functional strategy to resolve the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]]. The framework was set forth in a 2007 report by the [[Center for American Progress]], a [[Progressivism|progressive]] [[think tank]] based in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/strategic_reset.html Center for American Progress: "Strategic Reset"] retrieved 27 June 2007</ref>
==Background== The [[Center for American Progress]] developed the framework for strategic reset on the premise that "with the [[Iraq War]] well into its fifth year, the [[George W. Bush Administration|Bush administration]] still lacks a realistic plan for the Middle East and Iraq."<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/strategic_reset.html www.americanprogress.org] retrieved 27 June 2007</ref> Senior Fellows Brian Katulis and [[Lawrence Korb|Lawrence J. Korb]], together with Peter Juul, laid out the plan in the form of a 64-page report released [[June 25, 2007]].
In 2007, when retired [[U.S. Marine Corps]] Gen. [[John J. Sheehan]] published a newspaper [[editorial]] explaining his decision not to accept the position of "War Czar" or [[War Czar|White House implementation manager]] for the conflicts in Iraq and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]], he wrote: * "What I found in discussions with current and former members of this administration is that there is no agreed-upon strategic view of the Iraq problem or the region. ... <nowiki>[A]</nowiki>fter thoughtful discussions with people both in and outside of this administration, I concluded that the current Washington decision-making process lacks a linkage to a broader view of the region and how the parts fit together strategically."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/15/AR2007041500564.html "Why I Declined to Serve.” ''Washington Post'', 16 Apr 2007] qtd. in CAP</ref>
Citing Gen. Sheehan, the report gives examples from what are described as seven years of relative progress in the Middle East (1994–2000) followed by seven years of setbacks (2001–2007), such as:<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP Report]</ref> [[File:Oil Prices Medium Term.png|333px|right]] *decline and stall of the Arab–Israeli [[List of Middle East peace proposals|peace process]] followed by irruption of [[2006 Lebanon War|war]] between [[Israel]] and [[Hezbollah]] *Late 1990s [[containment]] and [[International sanctions|sanction]] of Iraq replaced by [[refugees of Iraq|refugee]] crises and [[Iraq War|war]] *[[Iran]]'s new global influence and increased progress on its [[nuclear program of Iran|nuclear program]] *[[Hamas]]' movement from margin to center of its political stage and victory in the [[Palestinian legislative election, 2006]]. *[[Direct relationship|Direct relation]] of [[price of petroleum|oil prices]] to rising levels of violence in the [[Middle East]]
[[Iraq War troop surge of 2007|U.S. strategy]] in Iraq in 2007 relied on Iraqi [[politics of Iraq|political progress]], increased numbers of U.S. troops in the country, and diversification of tactics for political and economic support.<ref name="whitehouse.gov">[https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/01/20070110-3.html Fact Sheet: The New Way Forward in Iraq]</ref> While proponents of strategic reset supported diversification, particularly as it regards "situat<nowiki>[ing]</nowiki> the strategy in a regional approach,"<ref name="whitehouse.gov"/> they strongly oppose sending more U.S. troops to Iraq, and they maintain that the "fundamental premise of Bush's surge strategy—that Iraq's leaders will make key decisions to advance their country's political transition and national reconciliation—is at best misguided and clearly unworkable."<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/strategic_reset.html Center for American Progress]</ref>
In 2006, the bipartisan [[Iraq Study Group]] released a [[Iraq Study Group Report|report]] stressing the need for troop withdrawal and for redoubled diplomatic efforts, including efforts to address the Arab–Israeli conflict.<ref>[http://www.usip.org/isg/iraq_study_group_report/report/1206/iraq_study_group_report.pdf Iraq Study Group Report] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601191410/http://www.usip.org/isg/iraq_study_group_report/report/1206/iraq_study_group_report.pdf |date=2009-06-01}} pp 6–7, retrieved 28 June 2007</ref> The report also said that the Iraqi government "should accelerate assuming responsibility for Iraqi security," and that the "primary mission of U.S. forces in Iraq should evolve to one of supporting the [[Military of Iraq|Iraqi army]], which would take over primary responsibility for combat operations."<ref>[http://www.usip.org/isg/iraq_study_group_report/report/1206/iraq_study_group_report.pdf Iraq Study Group Report] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601191410/http://www.usip.org/isg/iraq_study_group_report/report/1206/iraq_study_group_report.pdf |date=2009-06-01}} p 7, retrieved 28 June 2007</ref> Supporters of the strategic reset framework disagree with the latter terms, claiming that "the ISG was examining an Iraq that simply does not exist anymore," and that embedding U.S. forces to support Iraqi ones "would create unmanageable force protection problems for U.S. troops."<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP "Strategic Reset"] p 6 retrieved 28 June 2007</ref> Strategic reset emphasizes making [[counterterrorism]] the primary role of U.S. troops, rather than engaging them in [[Sectarian violence in Iraq (2006–07)|sectarian]] conflict.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP "Strategic Reset"] p 30 retrieved 28 June 2007</ref> It also emphasizes the necessity of recognizing Iraq's failed national reconciliation and adapting U.S. [[American intervention in the Middle East|policy]] to the inevitable decentralization of Iraqi politics.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP "Strategic Reset"] p 10 retrieved 28 June 2007</ref>
In 2007, the ''[[Washington Post]]'' described as "strategic reset" a proposal by U.S. Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] that took the form of "an unusually detailed public explanation of the new American effort to create a de facto alliance between Israel and moderate Arab states against Iranian extremism."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/25/AR2007012501555.html "Rice's Strategic Reset." ''Washington Post'' 26 Jan 2007]</ref>
==Principles of the strategic reset framework== Advocates of strategic reset maintain that the current administration's misjudgments regarding Iraq policy have jeopardized the United States' [[national security]] interests and that it must act now in order to prevent further [[attrition warfare|attrition]] of its military and to effectively confront a growing global terrorist threat. The strategy requires that U.S. troops rapidly be withdrawn from Iraq and enlisted in efforts to counter this threat, while available political resources are deployed throughout the Middle East in order to minimize conflict in Iraq and to ensure stability in the region at large. It also requires the U.S. to take action on several fronts, especially the Arab–Israeli conflict, in order to build international support and promote regional commitment to this stability. A further requirement is that the international community cooperate to promote [[rule of law]] and to encourage legitimate, non-aggressive governments in the Middle East, preventing the formation of "[[power vacuum|security vacuums]]" exploited by [[Al Qaeda]].<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/strategic_reset.html CAP] retrieved 28 June 2006</ref>
===Adapting to Iraq's fragmentation=== Since 2005, Iraq's major sectarian conflicts have continued to generate violence at high levels, and Iraq has failed to engineer a political solution to the problems that fuel them.<ref>[http://www.brookings.edu/views/op-ed/ohanlon/20070610.htm Brookings Institution] retrieved 28 June 2007</ref> In northern Iraq, [[Iraqi Turkmen|Turkmen]], [[Kurds]], and [[Arab]]s are fighting over the jurisdiction of the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]], and [[Turkey]] is conducting raids on the [[Kurdistan Workers Party]].<ref>[http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/detaylar.do?load=detay&link=115251 ''Today's Zaman''] retrieved 28 June 2007</ref> In the south and west, respectively, there is intra-[[Shi'a]] violence and violence between [[Iraq]]i [[Sunni]]s and Sunnis linked to [[Al-Qaeda]]; [[Baghdad]] and surrounding areas host the deadliest violence in the form of [[Civil war in Iraq (2006-07)|civil war]] between Sunni and Shi'a.<ref name="CAP report">[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report] p 5 retrieved 28 June 2007</ref> Proponents of strategic reset point out that no significant progress has been made on "benchmarks" established by U.S. Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] such as constitutional reform or laws regulating provincial [[election]]s, distribution of [[petroleum|oil]] revenue, or treatment of citizens subject to [[de-Baathification]]; they argue that no realistic policy can predicate the resolution of Iraq's sectarian conflicts on the rule of a unified Iraqi governing authority. On June 26, 2007, for example, Iraqi [[commando]]s raided the house of Culture Minister Asad Kamal al-Hashimi, who is believed to have ordered an assassination attempt fatal to both sons of Mithal al-Alusi, a member of Iraq's [[Council of Representatives (Iraq)|parliament]].<ref>[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/world/4921926.html "Sunni Leaders Angry Over Arrest Warrant." ''Houston Chronicle'' 26 June 2007]</ref> According to the CAP, "Iraq's leaders fundamentally disagree on what kind of country Iraq is and should be, and Iraq's political transition has not succeeded in bridging these divides. This lack of political consensus among Iraq's leaders has resulted in a violent struggle for power."<ref name="CAP report"/>
====Stopping unconditional arming of security forces==== [[File:Iraqi Police.jpg|thumb|right|Iraqi police on patrol in [[Karabilah]] after an [[Improvised explosive device|IED]] was found in a girls school]] Under the strategic reset framework, one immediate response to the political [[stalemate]] is cessation of the ongoing provision of weapons to [[Iraqi Security Forces|Iraqi security forces]], whose number now exceeds 500,000. According to the CAP, these security forces—who continue to receive considerable U.S. support—exhibit divided loyalties that stem directly from divisions in the political structure; they have been implicated in corruption, militia membership, death squads, and killing American troops sent to train them. "The fundamental problem with Iraq's security forces is that they lack the allegiance and in many cases the motivation to defend their country. The United States has poured more than [[$US|$]]20 billion into building a national army and police force that does not have the unity and support of its own leaders."<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report] pp 16–18 retrieved 28 June 2007</ref> Supporters of the strategic reset see two dangers in allowing the current policy of arming and training these security forces to continue: the first danger is that the U.S. is providing weaponry to opposing sides of a [[Civil war in Iraq (2006-07)|civil war]]. For example, [[Matthew Yglesias]], writing for ''[[The Atlantic]]'', has said, *"<nowiki>[T]</nowiki>his business of arming and training Iraqi security forces in the absence of a political solution is not just a waste of time and money, but directly counterproductive. Our weapons and funding are fueling civil conflict in the face of deep political fragmentation and there are absolutely no guarantees as to who these arms will be turned against next year or the year after that."<ref>[http://matthewyglesias.theatlantic.com/archives/2007/06/strategic_reset.php "Strategic Reset," ''The Atlantic'' Online, 25 Jun 2007] retrieved 29 June 2007</ref>
The second danger arises from the fact that the majority of Iraq's security forces are Shi'a who constitute "some of the closest allies of America's greatest rival in the Middle East—[[Iran]]."<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report] pp 13–14 retrieved 28 June 2007</ref>
====Decentralization==== A second response to fragmentation in Iraqi politics is decentralization of U.S. policy and power structure in Iraq. The strategic reset framework calls for reassignment of personnel from the [[Embassy of the United States in Baghdad|U.S. Embassy in Baghdad]] into "provincial outposts" established throughout Iraq. It also calls for the U.S. to forgo building a new Baghdad embassy, one projected to be the world's largest. According to the report, the adoption of this pragmatic, localized approach to placing diplomats and intelligence employees would represent progress on three fronts: It would provide bases for intelligence operations to counter [[terrorism]], allow U.S. officials to give [[consulate|consular]] support to Iraq's estimated 2 million internally [[displaced persons]], and bring U.S. personnel into closer working relationships with local Iraqi institutions.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report] p 22 retrieved 28 June 2007</ref>
===Phased military redeployment=== [[Phased redeployment]] is the strategic reset framework's second mainstay. The plan calls for the U.S. immediately to announce "that it does not intend to maintain permanent military bases or forces in Iraq" and to initiate a new deployment structure allowing forces currently serving in Iraq to rotate home, while incoming troops conduct counterterrorism missions from locations such as [[Turkey]], [[Afghanistan]], and [[Kuwait]]. A temporary force of 8,000–10,000 should remain in northern Iraq until 2009, but virtually all other troops are to leave Iraq by September 2008.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report] pp 27–29</ref> Redeployment is crucial to the reset strategy chiefly because of its potential to undermine terrorism: proponents argue that U.S. military presence in Iraq gives Al-Qaeda a powerful recruiting tool, as well as ideological justification for continued violence. The most damaging blow the U.S. can deal to such organizations in Iraq, they argue, is to withdraw. [[Ayman al-Zawahiri|Ayman al-Zawahri]] said on May 5, 2007, that a proposed U.S. redeployment would "deprive us of the opportunity to destroy the American forces which we have caught in a historic trap."<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/story?id=3143623 ABC News 5 May 2007]</ref>
The reset would remove U.S. troops from Iraq while preserving the ability to strike terrorist targets there and elsewhere. The "post-redeployment U.S. force structure in the Middle East would include: an [[United States Army|Army]] [[brigade]] and a tactical air [[Squadron (aviation)|squadron]] stationed in Kuwait; two light, mobile Army brigades stationed in the northern Kurdish areas [of Iraq]; a Marine Expeditionary unit afloat in the Persian Gulf; and four to five Army combat brigades stationed in Afghanistan to complete the unaccomplished mission of eradicating [[Al Qaeda]] there.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report] p 29</ref>
===Security and diplomacy=== The plan combines [[redeployment]] with initiatives to promote security and diplomacy in the [[Middle East]]. These include: *Increased efforts to enlist Iraq's neighboring countries in regional progress toward stabilization. The strategy proposes to involve these neighbors by alerting them to the potential local costs of further destabilization; it also suggests that the presence of redeployed U.S. forces will act as a deterrent to those who might otherwise be tempted to exploit Iraq's current weakness.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report p 33]</ref> *Specific measures to prevent escalation of conflict among [[Kurds]], [[Iraqi Turkmen|Turkmen]]s, and [[Arab]]s near the northern city of [[Kirkuk]]. Kirkuk, rich in oil and populated by a Kurdish majority, is the subject of a scheduled [[referendum]] that is expected to result in the city becoming part of [[Iraqi Kurdistan]]—a prospect frightening to Kirkuk's [[minority group|minorities]] as well as to its neighbors [[Turkey]] and [[Syria]].<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118290539957349396?mod=googlenews_wsj "Why Iraq's Kirkuk Is Vital," ''Wall Street Journal'' 27 June 2007]</ref> *Security initiatives aimed at [[jihadists]] returning to find targets for violence in their home countries once the United States has left Iraq. The strategic reset capitalizes on connections forged between intelligence networks and local authorities by increased diplomatic efforts.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report p 36]</ref> *Humanitarian aid to Iraq's refugees. Some 4 million Iraqis have been displaced by the conflict, fleeing either to [[Egypt]], [[Syria]], [[Jordan]] and countries in the [[Persian Gulf|Persian Gulf region]]; or to locations mostly within southern and central Iraq.<ref>[https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=22786&Cr=Iraq&Cr1= United Nations press release]</ref> The strategy aims to build international support for these [[displaced persons]]. It also suggests that, for [[morality|moral]] as well as for political reasons, the U.S. should sharply increase the number of Iraqi refugees it annually accepts, from the current 7,000 up to 100,000.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report p 5]</ref>
===Arab–Israeli conflict=== [[File:Mauer-betlehem.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Israeli West Bank barrier]]]] Strategic reset requires that U.S. diplomatic efforts to resolve the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]] be significantly upgraded. The first major reason for this requirement is that the conflict is considered to have deep destabilizing effects on the entire region; the second is that, since the conflict is seen as a driving force behind [[anti-American sentiment]],<ref>[http://meria.idc.ac.il/journal/2003/issue4/jv7n4a6.html "Causes of Anti-Americanism in the Arab World"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060907051421/http://meria.idc.ac.il/journal/2003/issue4/jv7n4a6.html |date=2006-09-07 }} ''Middle East Review of International Affairs''</ref> enhanced American participation in the [[List of Middle East peace proposals#Arab–Israeli peace diplomacy and treaties|peace process]] would leave the U.S. in a stronger political position regionally. The strategy calls for [[George W. Bush|President Bush]] to appoint a Middle East envoy and two senior [[ambassador]]s as an initial step in this direction.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report p 42]</ref> Further key steps would include: *Strategies to manage crises such as the [[Fatah–Hamas conflict]] *Provision of a diplomatic framework to coordinate regional and international peace proposals *Diplomatic outreach to [[Iran]] and [[Syria]] similar to U.S. [[Cold War]] diplomatic strategy with [[China]] and the [[Soviet Union]] *"Smartly targeted" [[rule of law]] support to alleviate [[power vacuum|security vacuums]] caused by political instability<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/06/pdf/iraq_report.pdf CAP report p 44]</ref>
==Criticisms== David Gooden, writing for the ''[[Des Moines Register]]'', has criticized the proposal as "imperial liberalism," claiming that "[F]oreign military occupations are the root cause of Islamic terrorism" and that "[t]he Center for American Progress' plan for a 'strategic reset' will not achieve a lasting or a just peace."<ref>[http://blogs.dmregister.com/?p=6625 "Imperial liberalism on display: 'progressive' think-tank calls for 'redeployment'"] ''Des Moines Register'', 26 Jun 2007</ref>

== Background (1920–1974) == * July 1920, [[Koçgiri Rebellion]] * September 3, 1924, [[Beytüşşebap rebellion]] ''(tr:Beytüşşebap İsyanı)'' * May 26, 1927, [[Mutki rebellion]] * October 1927, [[Ararat rebellion]] * July 7, 1930, [[Seyidan and Berazan rebellion]] ''(tr:Tutaklı Alican İsyanı)'' * 1930, [[Savur rebellion]] ''(tr:Savur Tenkil Harekâtı)'' * March 20, 1937, [[Dersim Rebellion]]
== 1974–1984: Rise of PKK == *March 18, 1977, [[Haki Karer]], a leader of the "Revolutionaries of Kurdistan" group is assassinated in [[Gaziantep]].<ref name="abdullah"/> *May 18, 1978, [[Halil Çavgun]], another "Revolutionaries of Kurdistan" leader is assassinated by Kurdish landowners.<ref name="abdullah"/> *November 27, 1978, the founding congress of the Kurdistan Workers' Party is held in the village of Fis near [[Lice, Turkey|Lice]] in [[Diyarbakır Province]].<ref name="abdullah"/> *December 25, 1978, [[Grey Wolves (organization)|Grey Wolves]] commit [[Maraş Massacre]], killing 109 and injuring 176 [[Alevi|Alevi Turks/]]Kurds in [[Kahramanmaraş]].<ref name=david>A modern history of the Kurds, By David McDowall, page 415, at [https://books.google.com/books?id=1tarN6gfxX8C&pg=PA415&lpg=PA415&dq=Maras+Massacre&source=bl&ots=VugE6xVwFk&sig=_gQUK4y0PGbXNK5qjQNJC9lwUvc&hl=en&ei=B-4tTPyoC4OBlAf0pMnhCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=Maras%20Massacre&f=false Google Books], accessed on May 1, 2011</ref> *September 12, 1980, [[General Staff of the Republic of Turkey|General]] [[Kenan Evren]] seizes power, deposing an elected government led by [[Süleyman Demirel]] and his [[Justice Party (Turkey)|Justice Party]] in the [[1980 Turkish coup d'état]]. Most of the PKK's leadership move to [[Syria]].<ref name="abdullah"/> *November 10, 1980, The Turkish Consulate in Strasbourg, France was bombed causing significant material damage but no injuries. In a telephone call to the Agence France-Presse office, a spokesman said the blast was a joint operation and marked the start of a "fruitful collaboration" between the [[Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia]] (ASALA) and the Kurdistan Workers Party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tkb.org/Incident.jsp?incID=249|title=ASALA and PKK attacked Diplomatic target (1980-11-10, France)|publisher=MIPT|accessdate=March 23, 2007}}</ref> *September 24, 1981, [[1981 Turkish consulate attack in Paris|the Turkish consulate in Paris is attacked]] by ASALA. Their demands included the release of five Kurdish revolutionary fighters.<ref name="prison">See the online edition [http://www.gundem-online.com/yazdir.asp?haberid=55278 of Gündem of July 14, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711133504/http://www.gundem-online.com/yazdir.asp?haberid=55278 |date=July 11, 2011 }} (Turkish); accessed on September 18, 2009</ref> *March 21, 1982, imprisoned PKK leader [[Mazlum Doğan]] burned himself to death in protest of the treatment of inmates at the [[Diyarbakır Prison]]. *May 7, 1982, PKK members [[Ferhat Kurtay]], [[Necmi Önen]], [[Mahmut Zengin]] and [[Eşref Anyık]] also burn themselves to death in Diyarbakır Prison.<ref name="prison"/> *June 6, 1982, start of the [[1982 Lebanon War|First Lebanon War]], PKK forces stationed in the [[Beqaa Valley]] are ordered to fight alongside the [[Palestinian Liberation Organisation]] (PLO) and Syria, against [[Israel]].<ref name="abdullah"/> *July 14, 1982, PKK members [[Kemal Pir]], [[M. Hayri Durmuş]], [[Ali Çiçek]] and [[Akif Yılmaz]] start a hunger strike in Diyarbakır Prison.<ref name="prison"/> *August 20–25, 1982, the second PKK congress is held in [[Daraa]], Syria.<ref name="abdullah"/> *September 7, 1982, Kemal Pir dies as result of his hunger strike in Diyarbakır Prison. M. Hayri Durmuş dies on September 12, Akif Yılmaz on September 15 and Ali Çiçek on September 15.<ref>Report of the [[Human Rights Foundation of Turkey]]: File of Torture: Deaths in Detention Places or Prisons (September 12, 1980 to September 12, 1995, Ankara, March 1996 {{ISBN|9757217093}}, page 68</ref> *April 12, 1984, a 75-day hunger-strike is started by Kurdish prisoners in [[Istanbul]]. Four prisoners die as result of the hunger-strike.
== 1984–1999: First insurgency == *August 15, 1984, the PKK starts the armed Kurdish rebellion with an [[15 August 1984 PKK attacks|attack]] on police and gendarmerie bases in [[Şemdinli]], [[Hakkâri Province]] and [[Eruh]], [[Siirt Province]]. *August 17, 1984, the PKK raids a police station in [[Siirt]].<ref name="weekly"/> *March 21, 1986, the PKK's military commander: [[Mahsum Korkmaz]] aka "Agit" is killed by Turkish forces.<ref name="abdullah"/> *July 19, 1987, the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey]] declared a civil state of emergency in 10 Southeastern provinces in response to the PKK's insurgency.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QuQBdYSc4d8C&pg=PA16 |title=The Kurdish Conflict|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> *February 5, 1990, over 500 Iraqi Kurds protested in Diyarbakir and clashed with Turkish security forces. Ninety-five people were arrested.<ref name="asylumlawkurds">[http://www.asylumlaw.org/docs/turkey/mar99_turkey_kurds.pdf Turkey Kurds] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716081035/http://www.asylumlaw.org/docs/turkey/mar99_turkey_kurds.pdf |date=July 16, 2011 }}</ref> *March 14, 1990, start of Kurdish popular protests and civil uprising known as [[Serhildan]] and in the city of [[Nusaybin]]. *May 27, 1990, about 100 Kurdish political prisoners went on hunger strike.<ref name="asylumlawkurds"/> *June 2, 1990, during a protest by 2,000 Iraqi Kurds, five protesters and a policeman were killed.<ref name="asylumlawkurds"/> *June 8, 1990, ten Kurdish MPs, led by [[Ahmet Fehmi Işıklar]] from the [[Social Democratic Populist Party (Turkey)|Social Democratic Populist Party]] broke away from the party to form Turkey's first pro-Kurdish party: the [[People's Labor Party]] (HEP).<ref name="asylumlawkurds"/> *August 28, 1990, a Kurdish representative to the [[United Nations Commission on Human Rights]] accused Turkey of using the [[Gulf Crisis]] to forcibly expel thousands of Kurds from their mountain homeland and executing those who refused to leave. The government of Turkey denied the accusation.<ref name="asylumlawkurds"/> *February 1, 1991, the Turkish government eased the ban on the [[Kurdish language]], by lifting the ban on speaking Kurdish and the ban on [[Kurdish music]]. However, the use of Kurdish was still forbidden in printed material, public gatherings, demonstrations and education.<ref name="asylumlawkurds"/> *March 2, 1991, during a major riot in Diyarbakir nearly 1000 Kurds fought troops with stones and sticks. Two Kurds and one Turkish soldier were killed.<ref name="asylumlawkurds"/> *April 1991, [[Yasilova incident|Yeşilova incident]] between British [[Royal Marines]] protecting Iraqi-Kurdish refugees, and [[Turkish Armed Forces]] allegedly preventing the refugees from receiving aid, in a refugee camp in [[Yeşilova]]. *August 18–21, 1992, [[Battle of Şırnak]], between Turkish armed forces and PKK fighters in the town of [[Şırnak]] leading to the destruction of much of the town. *October 3, 1992, start of [[Battle of Kulp|similar operations]] in the town of [[Kulp, Turkey|Kulp]] in [[Diyarbakır Province]]. *October 5, 1992, Turkey launches [[Operation Northern Iraq]] to support the [[Kurdistan Democratic Party]] (KDP) and [[Patriotic Union of Kurdistan]] in an armed conflict with the PKK in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]]. *November 17, 1992, truce signed between the KDP, PUK and PKK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,MARP,,TUR,,469f38e91e,0.html|title=Refworld - Chronology for Kurds in Turkey|author=United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|work=Refworld|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> *March 20, 1993 - PKK unilateral cease-fire declaration. Turkish President [[Turgut Özal]] plans pro-Kurdish reform package, but dies in office (17 April 1993) before he can bring it forward (see [[Castle Plan]] and [[1993 alleged Turkish military coup]]). *May 24, 1993, the PKK kills 33 unarmed Turkish soldiers in [[May 24, 1993 PKK ambush|an ambush]] on the highway between [[Elazığ]] and [[Bingöl]] *July 5, 1993, 100 militants [[Başbağlar massacre|attack the village of Başbağlar]], near [[Erzincan]], killing 33 civilians. The Turkish government claimed the PKK to be responsible for the massacre. *July 1993, the HEP is banned by the [[Constitutional Court of Turkey]].<ref>Güney 2002, 124.</ref> *May 11, 1994, Kurdish lawyer [[Murat Bozlak]] formed the [[People's Democracy Party]] (HADEP),<ref name="HADEP">{{cite web|url=http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/eng/pages/search.aspx#{"dmdocnumber":["878622"],"itemid":["001-102256"]}|title=HUDOC Search Page|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> *November 1994 – March 1995, Turkish [[Winter Campaign of 1994-1995|Winter Campaign]] to cut the PKK off from their winter supplies. *March 20 – May 4, 1995, Turkish [[Operation Steel]] against PKK forces in Northern [[Iraq]]. The operation was relatively unsuccessful because PKK forces had enough time to withdraw during the military buildup. The Operation ended on May 4 and resulted in displacement of over 15,000 Iraqi Kurds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asylumlaw.org/docs/turkey/mar99_turkey_kurds.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716081035/http://www.asylumlaw.org/docs/turkey/mar99_turkey_kurds.pdf |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |df= }}</ref> **April 19, 1995 Turkish Troops and aircraft laid siege to Kurdish PKK rebels in eastern Turkey as Ankara's military offensive in northern Iraq entetered a fifth week, in the Alibogazi ravine area in [[Tunceli]] province.<ref>{{cite news |title=WORLD NEWS HIGHLIGHTS|newspaper=Daily News|date=February 1, 1934|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=P-MJmu9ZMwQC&dat=19950419&printsec=frontpage}}</ref> *December 24, 1995, during the [[Turkish general election, 1995|Turkish general election of 1995]] the HADEP won 1,171,623 or 4.17% of the votes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tbmm.gov.tr/develop/owa/secimler.secimdeki_partiler?p_secim_yili=1995|title=Türkiye Büyük Millet Meclisi İnternet Sitesi|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> *1997, 4 Turkish soldiers are killed in the [[Sazak assault]], a joint operation between the PKK, the [[DHKP/C]] and [[TKP/ML]] near the city of [[Reşadiye]] in [[Tokat Province]].<ref name="sundayszaman">{{cite web|url=http://www.sundayszaman.com/sunday/newsDetail_getNewsById.action?newsId=195016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728032552/http://www.sundayszaman.com/sunday/newsDetail_getNewsById.action?newsId=195016 |archive-date=2011-07-28 |dead-url=yes|title=Tension high as heinous attack leaves unanswered questions behind - Today's Zaman, your gateway to Turkish daily news|accessdate=April 3, 2015}}</ref> *May July 12–7, 1997, Turkish and KDP forces launch [[Operation Hammer (1997)|Operation Hammer]] against the PKK in Iraqi Kurdistan during the [[Iraqi Kurdish Civil War]]. *September 25 – October 15, 1997, Turkish [[Operation Dawn (1997)|Operation Dawn]], a second intervention to support the KDP against the PKK in the civil war in Iraqi Kurdistan. *April 23, 1998,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qwBdLcnlu_oC&pg=PA204 |title=The Kurdish Conflict in Turkey|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> 40,000 Turkish troops are used in [[Operation Murat]], the largest military operation in the history of the Republic of Turkey (1925–present)<ref name="helsinki">{{cite web|url=http://ethesis.helsinki.fi/julkaisut/val/sospo/vk/koivunen/theinvis.pdf |title=http://ethesis.helsinki.fi/julkaisut/val/sospo/vk/koivunen/theinvis.pdf |page=102 |publisher=ethesis.helsinki.fi|accessdate=April 3, 2015}}</ref> attacking PKK forces in Kulp, Lice and [[Hani, Turkey|Hani]] in Diyarbakır Province and [[Genç, Bingöl|Genç]] in [[Bingöl Province]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=from-the-papers-1998-04-28|title=TURKEY - From the papers|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> In Kulp Turkish forces managed to corner senior PKK commande [[Murat Karayılan]], however he managed to escape and retreat into Iraqi Kurdistan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com.hk/node/170044|title=The Economist - World News, Politics, Economics, Business & Finance|work=The Economist|accessdate=February 11, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324135945/http://www.economist.com.hk/node/170044|archivedate=March 24, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *October 9,<ref name="weekly"/> 1998, Abdullah Öcalan is forced to leave [[Syria]] and go to [[Moscow]], [[Russia]].<ref name="Öcalan">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/articles/macleans/kurdish-terrorist-captured|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020164448/http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/articles/macleans/kurdish-terrorist-captured |archive-date=2012-10-20 |dead-url=yes|title=Kurdish Terrorist Captured - The Canadian Encyclopedia|author=TOM FENNELL with LAURIE UDESKY in Istanbul|accessdate=April 3, 2015}}</ref> *February 1, 1999, Abdullah Öcalan arrives at Greek island of [[Corfu]] and flown to [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] on February 2.<ref name="Öcalan"/> *February 15, 1999, Abdullah Öcalan is captured in Nairobi, Kenya and brought to Turkey to stand trial<ref name="Öcalan"/> *February 15 – February 18, [[February 1999 Kurdish protests]] break out worldwide against the arrest of Abdullah Öcalan, attacking Greek, Kenyan and Turkish diplomatic missions worldwide.<ref name="Öcalan"/> *March 13, 1999, a petrol [[1999 Istanbul bombings|bomb was detonated at a crowded shopping center in Istanbul]], killing 13 people. The next day two people, including a soldier are injured in [[Bahçelievler]] by a bomb placed under a truck. Turkish police suspect the PKK was behind the attacks. *April 18, 1999, during the [[Turkish general election, 1999|general election]] HADEP won 1,482,196 or 4.75% of the votes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/turkish/180499.shtml|title=SE脟陌M 2002 - BBC Turkish Service - BBC World Service|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> During [[Turkish local elections, 1999|local elections]] that same day, the party received 1,094,761 or 3.48% of the votes. *September 1, 1999, the PKK declares a unilateral 10 year cease-fire. End of the first insurgency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/para/pkk.htm|title=Kongra-Gel / Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK)|author=John Pike|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref>
== 1999–2004: Ceasefire == *January 17, 2000, the [[Kurdish Hezbollah]]'s leader [[Hüseyin Velioğlu]] is killed by Turkish forces in Istanbul.<ref name="turkishweekly">{{cite web|url=http://www.turkishweekly.net/article/180/turkish-hezbollah-hizbullah-kurdish-hezbollah.html |title=Turkish Hezbollah (Hizbullah) / Kurdish Hezbollah |publisher=turkishweekly.net |accessdate=April 3, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102143843/http://www.turkishweekly.net/article/180/turkish-hezbollah-hizbullah-kurdish-hezbollah.html |archivedate=January 2, 2015 |df= }}</ref> *February 2000, PKK declares formal end to the war.<ref name="HADEP"/> *April 10, 2002, the PKK abolished itself and formed to form a political organization named KADEK (Kurdistan Freedom and Democracy Congress), claiming the PKK had fulfilled its mission and would now move on as purely political organisation.<ref name="weekly"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ataa.org/reference/pkk/pkk.html|title=Assembly of Turkish American Associations|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> *May 13, 2003, members of Turkey's constitutional court decided unanimously to disband HADEP and ban the party.<ref name="HADEP"/> *November 2003, KADEK and the Kurdish parliament (KNK) were merged into a new organization named KONGRA-GEL.<ref name="weekly">{{cite web|url=http://www.turkishweekly.net/article/217/chronology-of-the-important-events-in-the-world-pkk-chronology-1976-2006-.html |title=Chronology of the Important Events in the World/PKK Chronology (1976-2006) |publisher=turkishweekly.net |accessdate=April 3, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101006073753/http://www.turkishweekly.net/article/217/chronology-of-the-important-events-in-the-world-pkk-chronology-1976-2006-.html |archivedate=October 6, 2010 |df= }}</ref> *January 13, 2004, the PKK and all its organizations were added to the [[U.S. State Department list of Foreign Terrorist Organizations]].<ref name="weekly"/> *April 5, 2004, the EU added the PKK to its list of designated terrorist organizations.<ref name="weekly"/> *June 1, 2004, after a power struggle between moderates and hardliners in the within the PKK is won by hardliners and [[Murat Karayılan]] becomes leader of the PKK, the group declares an end to the September 1999 ceasefire and start of the second insurgency.<ref name="weekly"/>
== 2004–2012: Second insurgency ==
===2005=== *July 2, 2005, six people are killed and 15 injured by a train bomb planted by Kurdish guerrillas, on a train travelling between Elâzığ and [[Tatvan]] in [[Bingöl province]].<ref name="recent"/> *July 6, 2005, a bombing at a holiday resort in [[Kuşadası]] kills at least five people including a British and an Irish citizen.<ref name="recent"/>
===2006=== *February 13, 2006, six people are injured in a bombing of an Istanbul supermarket. The [[Kurdistan Freedom Hawks]] (TAK) claim responsibility for the blast and vow more attacks.<ref name="recent">{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/10/19/uk-turkey-attacks-timeline-idUKTRE79I3VN20111019|title=Timeline - Recent Kurdish militant attacks in Turkey|publisher=|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref> *June 25, 2006, a bombing hits a tourist resort near [[Antalya]], killing four and injuring 28 people. The TAK claim responsibility for the attack.<ref name="recent"/> *August 27, 2006, ten British and six Turkish citizens are wounded in a minibus bombing in [[Marmaris]]. Five people are injured by two other bombs.<ref name="recent"/> *August 28, 2006, Three people are killed and 87 injured in a blast in Antalya. The TAK claim responsibility.<ref name="recent"/> *September 12, 2006, a bombing in Diyarbakir kills ten civilians. The [[Turkish Revenge Brigade]] (TİT) claimed responsibility for the attack on their website, threatening to kill ten Kurds for every Turk killed in the conflict.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/a-13-2006-09-13-voa48.html|title=Turkish Revenge Brigade Claims Responsibility for Bomb Blast in Kurdish Area|work=VOA|accessdate=February 11, 2015}}</ref>
===2007=== *May 22, 2007: A [[2007 Ankara bombing|suicide bombing hits Ankara]], killing eight and wounding over 100. This attack was attributed to the PKK and the Turkish army decided to launch a military action against them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.people.com.cn/200706/07/eng20070607_381956.html |work=People's Daily Online |title= Death toll in Ankara suicide bombing rises to eight |date= June 7, 2007|accessdate=October 12, 2008}}</ref> *May 31, 2007: The Turkish military announced they were prepared to launch an incursion into Iraq. Leader of Iraqi Kurdistan [[Massoud Barzani]] announced that the Peshmerga will defend itself in case of a Turkish incursion.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} *June 2, 2007: American troops and civilians have withdrawn from all of Iraqi Kurdistan. Massoud Barzani again warns the Turkish military that any incursion will be fought against by the Peshmerga. An estimated 100,000 Turkish troops are mobilized on the border between Turkey and Iraq.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} *June 4, 2007: A PKK grenade attack kills seven soldiers and wounds six at an army base in [[Tunceli]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6718965.stm |title=Seven Turks killed in rebel raid |publisher=BBC News|section=Europe|date= June 4, 2007|accessdate=October 12, 2008}}</ref> *June 5, 2007: There are reports of limited shelling and air strikes by the Turkish army attacking PKK bases in Iraqi Kurdistan. {{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} *June 7, 2007: Several hundred Turkish troops cross into Iraq on a "hot pursuit" raid against Turkish rebels.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4176/is_/ai_n19295261 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730070744/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4176/is_/ai_n19295261 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 30, 2013 |title=Stories differ on Turkish 'hot pursuit' into Iraq |work=Oakland Tribune|accessdate=October 12, 2008 }}</ref> Turkey declares a three-month martial law in Kurdish areas near the Iraq border and bans civilian flights to the area. It has been confirmed that 3 Turkish soldiers have been killed by a PKK landmine.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/08/AR2007060800462.html |title=Iraqi Kurds: Turkey Shells Across Border |work=The Washington Post |date= June 8, 2007|accessdate=September 25, 2010}}</ref> *September 27, 2007, two Turkish gendarme are killed in [[Bitlis Province]] by a bomb planted by Kurdish separatists.<ref name="recent"/> *October 7, 2007: [[October 7, 2007 Yüksekova incident|Yüksekova incident]]. 27 Turkish soldiers and 33 PKK militants are killed. *Oct 17, 2007: Turkish Grand National Assembly approves a government request for their troops to cross the Iraqi border to attack Kurdish rebels.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7049348.stm |section=Europe |title=Turkish MPs back attacks in Iraq |publisher=BBC News|date=October 18, 2007|accessdate=October 12, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Turkey approves Iraq incursion |publisher=CNN |date=October 17, 2007 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/meast/10/17/turkey.iraq/index.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209123709/http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/meast/10/17/turkey.iraq/index.html |archivedate=February 9, 2008 }}</ref> Action was delayed on request by the US government on the condition that "swift steps" were taken to deal with the militants. *Oct 21, 2007: 12 Turkish troops killed in [[21 October 2007 cross-border attack on Turkey|PKK ambush]] on their army post, less than three miles from the Iraq border.
[[File:Anti-PKK demonstration in Kadiköy.jpg|thumb|300px|right|A demonstration against the PKK in [[Kadıköy]], [[İstanbul]] on October 22, 2007]]
*October 24, 2007: Turkish fighter jets bombed several PKK targets on the Iraqi side of the border.<ref>"[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7059721.stm Turkish raids along Iraqi border]", ''[[BBC News]]'', October 24, 2007</ref>
===2008=== *January 3, 2008, a bomb attack against a military vehicle outside a school in Diyarbakır kills five and injures 110 people.<ref name="recent"/> *February 21, 2008: Turkey launches a [[2008 Turkish incursion into northern Iraq|ground incursion]] into northern Iraq, sending 10,000 troops across the border supported by air assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=10&categ_id=2&article_id=89347 |title= Turkish attacks in Iraq 'exclusively target PKK' |section=Politics|work=The Daily Star |accessdate=October 12, 2008}}</ref> A total of 27 Turkish soldiers and 724 PKK militants are killed. *May 9, 2008, three people are killed and five wounded in Batman province when a landmine destroys their minibus.<ref name="recent"/> *July 27, 2008: Turkey blames the PKK for [[2008 Istanbul bombings|two bombings in Istanbul]] which kill 17 and injure 154. *August 7, 2008: The PKK claimed responsibility for the explosion that halted the operation of the [[Baku–Tbilisi–Ceyhan pipeline|Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan oil pipeline]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c4836dca-64e1-11dd-af61-0000779fd18c.html |accessdate=September 15, 2008 |title=Kurds lay claim to blast on Azeri oil pipeline |work=Financial Times |date=August 8, 2008 |first=Alex |last=Barker }}</ref>
*October 1, 2008: One Turkish security force soldier was killed, with another one wounded, in an attack staged by PKK militants in southeastern Turkey.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-10/01/content_10138798.htm |title=PKK kills Turkish soldier in southeast |work=Xinhua |date=October 1, 2008 |accessdate=October 12, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007064855/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-10/01/content_10138798.htm |archivedate=October 7, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *October 4, 2008: Fifteen Turkish soldiers were killed, with another 20 also wounded, after a PKK attack from northern Iraq with the firing of heavy weapons at a military outpost in the [[Semdinli]] region bordering Iraq and Iran. At least 23 members of the PKK were also killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Fifteen_Turkish_soldiers_killed_in_clashes_with_PKK.html?siteSect=143&sid=9806118&cKey=1223147254000&ty=ti |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120911051148/http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Fifteen_Turkish_soldiers_killed_in_clashes_with_PKK.html?siteSect=143&sid=9806118&cKey=1223147254000&ty=ti |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 11, 2012 |title=Fifteen Turkish soldiers killed in clashes with PKK|work=Swissinfo.ch |accessdate=October 12, 2008}}</ref>
A statement issued after an emergency meeting of the Counter Terrorism Higher Board, chaired by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, said: "Our struggle against terrorism will be pursued under all conditions and above all other concerns through effective cooperation between state bodies and every measure will be implemented with determination."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-10/05/content_10149376.htm |title=Turkey vows to crush PKK rebels after 15 soldiers killed|work=Xinhua|date=October 5, 2008 |accessdate=October 12, 2008}}</ref>
The British foreign office said: "The United Kingdom utterly condemns Friday's terrorist attack in Hakkâri, Turkey. There can be no excuse for the use of violence to achieve one's aims. The UK stands shoulder-to-shoulder with Turkey in its fight against terrorism and strongly supports ongoing efforts between the Turkish and Iraqi authorities to prevent the PKK from using northern Iraq as a base from which to mount attacks against Turkey."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5ipEW55TUMPEFIhzE5GRze-Z99Ktg|title=Govt. 'utterly condemns' PKK attack on Turkish troops|date=October 4, 2008|work=Google|agency=[[Agence France Presse]]|accessdate=October 12, 2008}}<!-- back-up: http://www.dailyexpress.co.uk/posts/view/22730/Miliband-condemns-Kurdish-attack --></ref><ref>{{cite press release|publisher=[[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]]|date=October 23, 2007|title=MILIBAND CONDEMNS ATTACKS ON TURKEY-IRAQ BORDER|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/resources/en/press-release/2007/10/fco_hpnpr_211007_turkeyiraq}}</ref>
The European Union also condemned the on the [[gendarmerie]] station in a statement released by the Union's French presidency, saying: "Europe expresses its complete solidarity with the Turkish authorities and offers its condolences to the families and friends of the victims."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/english/home/10040135.asp |title=Europe condemns PKK attack on Turkish troops |work=Hurriyet English|accessdate=October 12, 2008}}</ref>
===2009=== *April 29, 2009, a PKK detonated bomb kills nine soldiers after ripping through their vehicle in Diyarbakir province.<ref name="recent"/> *May 4, 2009, Village Guards dressed as PKK fighters attack a wedding party with rifles and grenades, killing at least 44 people in a family feud.<ref name="recent"/> *May 28, 2009: 6 Turkish soldiers were killed and 7 others were reportedly injured when their vehicle struck a landmine, in the [[Hakkâri Province]] of south-eastern Turkey.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8071367.stm Turkish soldiers killed in blast]. BBC News (2009-05-28). Retrieved on August 20, 2010.</ref> *December 7, 2009: Seven Turkish soldiers were killed and three wounded in [[Resadiye shooting|an ambush]] in [[Resadiye]], Northern Turkey. The gunmen are suspected Kurdish militants, but their identities have not yet been confirmed.
===2010=== *March 14, 2010: 1 Turkish soldier was killed and another soldier was injured during a clash with PKK militants, in the [[Hakkâri Province]] of south-eastern Turkey.<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE62D0BR.htm Reuters AlertNet – Turkish soldier killed in clash with Kurd rebels]. Alertnet.org (2010-03-14). Retrieved on August 20, 2010.</ref> *April 15, 2010: 1 Turkish soldier was killed and 2 were wounded during clashes in the [[Batman Province|Batman]] province.<ref>[http://www.worldbulletin.net/news_detail.php?id=57125 Turkish troop killed in PKK clash [ WORLD BULLETIN- TURKEY NEWS, WORLD NEWS ]] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100419192740/http://www.worldbulletin.net/news_detail.php?id=57125 |date=April 19, 2010 }}. Worldbulletin.net (2010-04-16). Retrieved on August 20, 2010.</ref> In the [[Siirt Province]] 2 PKK militants were killed and 3 soldiers wounded.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kurdishglobe.net/displayArticle.jsp?id=502D1DB7AC2E102F881A7BAECAA2421C |title=Two Kurdish PKK rebels killed in southeast Turkey |publisher=KurdishGlobe |date=April 17, 2010 |accessdate=September 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612194836/http://kurdishglobe.net/displayArticle.jsp?id=502D1DB7AC2E102F881A7BAECAA2421C |archivedate=June 12, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *April 19, 2010: 2 Turkish police officers were killed after suspected PKK militants opened fire upon their police patrol car with automatic weapons in the northern Turkish province of [[Samsun]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=123726&sectionid=351020204 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.ir |accessdate=September 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001101136/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=123726&sectionid=351020204 |archivedate=October 1, 2012 }}</ref> *April 26, 2010: 1 Turkish soldier was killed and 2 others were reportedly wounded after a landmine detonated, as their military vehicle was crossing a bridge near to the town of [[Dereli]] within the [[Giresun province]].<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE63P1F8.htm Reuters AlertNet – Turkish soldier killed, two wounded by landmine]. Alertnet.org (2010-04-26). Retrieved on August 20, 2010.</ref> *April 29, 2010: 2 Turkish soldiers were killed and another 3 other soldiers were wounded in a clash with PKK militants within the [[Hakkâri Province]], in the south east of the country. These deaths and injuries come as the Turkish military launches a new military operation against PKK militants, in south eastern Turkey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=124812&sectionid=351020204 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.ir |accessdate=September 24, 2010}}</ref> *May 1, 2010: At least 4 Turkish soldiers were killed and another 7 others were apparently injured after PKK militants attacked a military command post within the [[Tunceli Province]], in eastern Turkey.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6400B420100501 Four Turkish soldiers killed in Kurd rebel attack]. Reuters. ==2015–present: Third insurgency==
===2015=== * 20 July 2015, [[2015 Suruç bombing|a bombing]] in the Kurdish district of [[Suruç]], allegedly perpetrated by the ISIL-linked [[Dokumacılar]] group, killed 32 young activists and injured over 100. Many Kurdish groups blamed Turkey for involvement or non-prevention of the terror act. Shortly, violence was reported in [[Adiyaman Province]], eastern Turkey that day. Fighters, identified by Turkey as PKK, fired on patrolling soldier with long-barreled rifles, killing a corporal and wounding two NCOs. While on patrol duty, the soldiers had discovered several caves filled with supplies by kurdish guerrilla.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/fallen-turkish-soldier-laid-to-rest-in-official-ceremony-in-adiyaman.aspx?pageID=238&nID=85732&NewsCatID=341|title=Fallen Turkish soldier laid to rest in official ceremony in Adıyaman - LOCAL|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> * 22 July - 2 Turkish police officers were killed in their home in [[Şanlıurfa Province]]; PKK claimed responsibility as revenge for the [[2015 Suruç bombing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/turkey/11755018/Two-Turkish-police-officers-killed-close-to-Syria-border.html|title=Kurdish militants claim 'revenge' killing of two Turkish policemen|date=22 July 2015|work=Telegraph}}</ref> * 23 July - 1 Turkish police officer was killed and another seriously wounded when masked PKK gunmen opened fire on them in [[Diyarbakir Province]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/video-policeman-killed-by-gunfire-in-southeast-turkey.aspx?pageID=238&nID=85831&NewsCatID=509|title=VIDEO: Policeman killed by gunfire in southeast Turkey - CRIME|work=hurriyetdailynews.com}}</ref> On the same day one soldier was killed and two wounded when shots were fired at a border checkpoint from beyond the [[Syria|Syrian border]]; Turkish security forces returned fire. The attack is currently blamed on Islamic State-linked jihadist militias.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-army-engages-in-first-gunfight-with-isil-after-soldier-killed-on-border.aspx?pageID=238&nID=85843&NewsCatID=359|title=As it happened: Turkish army engages in first gunfight with ISIL after soldier killed on border|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> * 24 July - Operation Martyr Yelcin was a launched by the [[Turkish Air Force]] against [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) positions in [[Syria]] and [[Kurdistan Workers' Party]] (PKK) positions in [[Northern Iraq]] on 24 and 25 July 2015.<ref name=Hurriyet24-7-15>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-airstrikes-target-isil-in-syria.aspx?pageID=238&nID=85853&NewsCatID=352|date=24 July 2015|accessdate=13 September 2015|title=Turkish airstrikes target ISIL in Syria|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> PKK bombed a police station in [[Diyarbakir Province]], wounding 7 police officers.<ref name="hurriyetdailynews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/two-soldiers-killed-4-others-injured-in-car-bombing-in-turkeys-southeast.aspx?pageID=238&nID=85924&NewsCatID=341|title=Two soldiers killed, 4 others injured in car bombing in Turkey's southeast|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> * 25 July - A PKK car bomb killed 2 Turkish soldiers and wounded 4 in [[Diyarbakir Province]]; hours later, masked kurdish guerillas attacked a police patrol in [[Istanbul]], severely wounding 3 police officers and lightly harming 1 civilian.<ref name="hurriyetdailynews.com"/> On the same day 15 construction workers and 1 police officer were abducted by PKK fighters in [[Sirnak Province]]. Shots were fired.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/mondo/europa/2015/07/25/turchia-15-operai-rapiti-dal-pkk_535471a7-54dd-44b5-a6fd-ba180c48b8a0.html|title=Turchia: 15 operai rapiti dal Pkk|work=ANSA}}</ref> * 26 July - 1 Turkish police officer killed by gunfire from inside a home in [[Istanbul]] while detaining terrorism suspects in the neighborhood. It is unclear whether PKK or the leftist [[DHKP-C]] is responsible for the shooting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/police-officer-killed-in-istanbul-amid-rising-violence-against-security-personnel.aspx?pageID=238&nID=85987&NewsCatID=509|title=Police officer killed in Istanbul amid rising violence against security personnel|work=Hurriyet Daily News}}</ref> * 27 July - 1 Turkish gendarmerie officer was killed in a PKK attack in Turkey's eastern [[Muş Province]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/gendarmerie-officer-killed-in-eastern-turkey.aspx?pageID=238&nID=86027&NewsCatID=341|title=Gendarmerie officer killed in eastern Turkey - LOCAL|work=hurriyetdailynews.com}}</ref> * 29 July - 3 Turkish soldiers were killed while securing a road in Sirnak in a coordinated PKK ambush. Both attacks resulted in no casualties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://national.bgnnews.com/military-hospital-in-turkeys-eastern-province-of-bitlis-attacked-by-pkk-haberi/8220|title=Military hospital in Turkey's eastern province of Bitlis attacked by PKK|work=Bugun}}</ref> * 4 August - 3 Turkish soldiers were killed in two separate attacks in [[Sirnak Province]]: [[Turkish gendarmerie]] [[Private (rank)|Private]] Abdülkadir Pektaş and [[Sergeant]] Mehmet Acar were killed by an IED explosion while patrolling near the village of Balveren. 1 Turkish soldier was killed by gunfire while patrolling the site of a PKK [[Arson|arson attack]] on vehicles in Turkey's south-eastern [[Van Province]]. 1 bus staff member was killed and three [[iran]]ian citizen were wounded too in the accident when kurdish fighters opened fire on an iranian bus refusing to stop at the PKK checkpoint.<ref name="national.bgnnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://national.bgnnews.com/turkish-master-sergeant-killed-in-operation-over-pkk-attack-of-iranian-bus-haberi/8351|title=Turkish master sergeant killed in operation over PKK attack of Iranian bus|work=Bugun}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailysabah.com/nation/2015/08/07/pkk-terrorists-kill-soldier-in-turkeys-southeastern-van-province|title=PKK terrorists kill soldier in Turkeys southeastern Van province|date=7 August 2015|work=Daily Sabah}}</ref> * 7 August - 1 Turkish police officer was killed and at least 1 wounded when PKK fired a [[Rocket-propelled grenade|rocked-propelled grenade]] against their armored vehicle while security forces were engaged on a riot control duty mission in Çizre, Sirnak Province. 3 police officers were also killed in separate attacks in Turkey's south-eastern provinces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/anasayfa_one-police-killed-in-pkk-attack-in-southeast-turkey_395964.html|title=One police killed in PKK attack in southeast Turkey|date=8 August 2015|work=Today's Zaman}}</ref><ref>[http://www.turkishweekly.net/2015/08/07/news/five-killed-as-pkk-continues-its-attacks-in-turkey/ Turkish Weekly]</ref> * 8 August - '''Vytautas Merkys''' (May 5, 1929 in Čivai, near [[Kupiškis]] – July 25, 2012<ref>{{cite news|title=A†A Prof. Vytautas Merkys (1929 05 05–2012 07 25)|url=http://www.voruta.lt/a%E2%80%A0a-prof-vytautas-merkys-1929-05-05%E2%80%932012-07-25/|accessdate=12 November 2014|publisher=voruta|date=5 August 2012}}</ref>) was a Lithuanian historian and a professor at [[Vilnius University]].
== Biography ==
Merkys graduated from Vilnius University's department of history and [[philology]] in 1951. In 1952 he began working at the [[Lithuanian Institute of History|Lithuanian SSR Institute of History]], but for ideological reasons he was soon fired, along with [[Mečislovas Jučas]]. He returned to the Institute in 1953 as a [[fellow]].
He initiated his candidacy for a [[doctorate of philosophy]] degree in 1957 with the thesis ''Revoliucinis Vilniaus miesto darbininkų judėjimas 1895–1904 m.'' (''The Revolutionary Movement of Vilnius City Workers from 1895 to 1904''), and in 1969 he was awarded a doctorate (the Soviet equivalent of [[habilitation]]) for his [[dissertation]] ''Lietuvos pramonės augimas ir proletariato formavimasis XIX amžiuje'' (''The Growth of Lithuanian Industry and the Formation of the Proletariat in the 19th Century'').
In 1986 he left the Institute and was designated head of the Department of Economic History at the Lithuanian SSR Academy of Sciences. He returned to the Institute of History in 1987 and became its director. Between 1992 and 2000 he was a senior fellow there. Merkys has been a professor at Vilnius University since 1991, and was a professor at [[Vytautas Magnus University]] from 1993 to 2000. In 1990 he was elected to the [[Lithuanian Academy of Sciences]], and since 2001 he has been a member of the [[Lithuanian Catholic Academy of Sciences]].
Vytautas Merkys received the Lithuanian presidential award, [[Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas]], third class, in 1995.
== Awards and recognition == * [[Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas]], Third Class, 1995 * [[Lithuanian science award]], 1997, for fundamental work on [[knygnešiai|the Lithuanian book smuggling movement between 1864-1904]]
== Important works ==
Vytautas Merkys' principal works focus on Lithuanian 19th-century and early 20th century history, especially the [[Lithuanian national revival]], [[knygnešiai|the Lithuanian book smuggling movement]] during the [[ban on the Lithuanian press]], the work of the 19th-century historian [[Simonas Daukantas]], and the life of the 19th-century bishop [[Motiejus Valančius]].
